reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is an educational tool like no other.

On the surface you will gain insights into how various types of plagues are spread and adapt to new surroundings and the methods that educated scientists use to slow that spread and eradicate them.

However, on a deeper and much more disturbing level you will realise how satisfied you are sneaking into a country undetected and mutating into a killer virus that wipes out the entire population in just a few days. You will pull your hair out with frustration as 3% of the world survives your onslaught because you were not quick enough to shut down vital organs. And finally you will learn that Greenland is magical place filled with people that always wash their hands, import nothing and travel nowhere.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Plague Inc is a rather satisfying simulation in which the player's goal is to infect and kill of the entire world. Just exactly how the player chooses to tackle this is up to them.

Gameplay

The player can choose to slowly infect the population, remaining undetected and non-lethal, and then strike once much of the world's population is infected by evolving lethality to kill fast and unexpectedly, making it difficult for the world to react and cure it in time or just try to kill the world as fast as possible which usually results in losing the game as many of the more isolated countries such as Greenland will shut their ports and airports making it very difficult to infect them.

Content

The player is not presented with just one disease type, but many. These disease types range from a neurax worm which allows the player to manipulate infected hosts to their advantage to the necroa virus which allows the player to unleash a devastating zombie apocalypse on the world. It doesn't stop here though as there is a rather extensive community workshop with countless unique diseases thanks to the scenario creator which is available to every player who owns the game.

More coming

The developers of this game are also working on a multiplayer mode which will see two players battle it out to see who's plague is superior. The game is also regularly updated with new content and bug fixes.

Conclusion

While Plague Inc is not perfect, it offers great replayability with different ways to beat different scenarios and higher difficulty modes which can really challenge the player. The price is rather steep so I would suggest waiting until the game is on sale to get the best value for money. 8/10 - Great game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Plague Inc.: Evolved; let me first start out by saying, this is exactly how the Early Access model should be done. This game is an absolute treat to play.

The main idea behind the game, if you don't already know (I’d be surprised if you didn't to be honest), is to develop, mutated and transmit your very own disease. You can choose which symptoms you would like your diseases to have, how you would like it to be transmitted around the world and many other different options. There are a number of different kinds of diseases you can choose, my favourite has to be the zombie plague; each of the different modes offers different symptoms, abilities and ways to transmit your creation as well.

The graphics are essentially a 2D world map; you don't need anything else for this game, the UI and HUD are very nicely put together and you can get all of the information you require within a key press.

Each of the different modes have been carefully crafted so that no game ever feels the same; this game really makes you think, would this symptom thrive in these conditions? How can I get my plague to travel to the other side of the world when all of the airports are closed? The possibilities are endless.

The game can also vary in difficulty; each different mode has 4 stages of difficulty; and boy oh boy does it get hard in the brutal stages. You are best of cracking out a guide if you want to tackle some of the harder stages.

I have played about ten hours so far; this has enabled me to complete all the different types of diseases and modes on offer, done a couple on Brutal difficulty and worked on a few achievements. There are still roughly 100 more achievements to collect along with the scenario modes to play; and given that they game is still in early access, I fully expect there to be more content added soon too.

I can 100% guarantee that anyone will enjoy this game; it’s a perfect pick up and play game but you can also get mind numbingly deep into the inner workings of diseases and plagues without having to do six years in medical school.

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As i am writing this, the game is still in early access. There are still missing features, most notably the Necroa Virus type, Tutorials & Scenarios. But allready the game is highly playable and damn addicting.

You are a plague, you infect people and evolve and the aim is to infect and kill everyone on earth in the end. There is strategy involved in picking the right mutations for your plague, keeping a low profile, not killing too many before you are discovered and later killing them fast enough before they can develop a cure for you.

There are several different plague types, Bacteria, Virus, Prion and more. They require different ways to evolve them to be sucessfull. The Neurax Worm which was added with the last patch was the most fun for me. The hunting for achievements was fun as well, altough alot of them arent implemented yet.

The game originally was made for mobiles and is now ported to the PC. It feels pretty good and polished for a port.
If i had one negative thing to say about the game then its about the bubble clicking, which gets tiresome and annoying after a while. Also it feels a bit too pricey, ~10 Euros would have been a much fairer pricepoint in my opinion.

You can get a mobid kind of satisfaction out of beeing sucessfull in this game, knowing that you just wiped out a whole planet. I just couldnt resist getting it, and overall i am sure i got my moneys worth out of it.

As long as you dont expect deep strategy you will have a good time with this game.
Its a nice timewaster with suprising complexity below its shell.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now that the multiplayer update is out, I figured I would go ahead and make a review of the game, now that it's mostly completed. The short answer: If you like strategy games, or are fascinated by the idea of creating your own pathogen to destroy humanity, buy this game, especially during a sale.

The details:

The base game is a genetic strategy game where your goal is to infect the world and destory it before they can do the same to you. It offers plenty of options for doing so, and the game is simple enough in the lower difficulties for newcomers to get a basic idea of what to do, but in harder difficulties, it is challenging enough for even veteran players to have a difficult challenge. The game has many different plague types and modes to try, including user created plagues.

The multiplayer mode is also fun, sporting many strategies that counter other strategies, with quite a bit of depth. Would advise AGAINST newcomers to the game from playing that mode first, as it is much more intense of an experience compared to the main game.  Against friends or randoms, the multiplayer is a great addition to an already great game.

I've played this game ever since 2012, whenever the game first started out on mobile devices and there was only 6 plagues and 3 difficulties. This game has kept my attention and still manages to be a fun distraction and experience to come back to time and time again. So, if you seem at all interested, pick it up, it's a strategy game that's worth the price.

P.S. This game will make you hate Greenland. You will understand why.

The fact that I like this game shouldn't detract from the fact that I can't recommend it.

This is a game meant to be played on a phone, and it shows.  It is very one-dimensional and once you've figured it out (should take about 15 minutes at most) that's it.  Sure there are levels and things to unlock, but the bottom line is that it should only be purchased on sale.  I paid full price and I regret it.

The rundown:

Early Access Review

A plague simulator with an infectious amount of replayablity. The graphics and gameplay are rather simple but the end goal is to dominate the world with those little red circles of infection.  Timing plays a huge role in evolving and deevolving traits depending on the type of infection.  For instance, if your plague is too severe before you attain widespread infection, humans will begin working on a cure before you have time enough to infect everyone.  Conversely, if you are too wide spread through transmission abilities, you might not end up with enough DNA to be lethal enough before a cure is found.

The Planet of the Apes add on is very interesting.  I'm still experimenting with it but unleashing a virus that makes apes more intelligent and combat humans is quite entertaining.  In fact, things got so bad in China once, the US decided to nuke em just to supress the spread of the virus.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*ah-heh-hem.*

Picture the most violent you can think of...

... that is a children's game compared to what I am about to describe to you.

Enter Plague Inc. No guns, no magic, you're a disease. You kill with fevers. You will with tumors! You kill with necrosis! You kill with Dysentery! You kill with zombies! You kill with brain worms! You kill with organ failures!

You kill the entire world! Billions will die by your microscopic hands. Men and women. Strong and weak. Rich and poor. Honest and deceitful. The last pitiful homosapien will die howling in agony, drowning in their own infected mucus and poisoned blood in some hole in the ground, covered in the twisted, freakish, unrecognizable remainss of what were once it's mate and spawn. You will leave the world empty, correcting the great cosmic error that was once the human race!

But don't think this will be easy. Oh no; the things will fight back. They're smart, they're rich, and they take pride in all the diseases they've wiped out in their short pitiful existance. Rich countries will put aside their differences and work together to add you to the tally of ailments they've purged from this planet. But for all their wealth and knowledge, even the scientists and doctors that they hide behind are still susceptable to you!

This is Plague Inc. The fun little game of human extinction  or enslavement.  And it's the nastiest out there!

reviewText:
Plague, Inc. is a smooth playing simulation and real-time strategy game. It is highly intriguing and elicits quite a few time-sensitive questions on a relevant topic today... for everyone. Whether you are concerned about Contagion, Plagues, last-days scenarios, or bio-terrorism; Plague, Inc. is there.

It doesn't take too many play-throughs to realize that not all diseases are created equal. But, the game does draw you to multiple play-throughs, as you spin out each scenario, captivated by the results of minor changes in your strategy. The game starts with a basic menu of disease types in the main-game portion: Bacteria, Virus, Fungus, Parasite, Prion, Nano-Virus, Neurax Worm, Bio-Weapon, and finally Necroa (Zombies) and the Simian Flu for those who want to turn Earth into the Planet of the Apes.

The game is overflowing with feature-rich side scenarios; from real diseases past and present like The Black Death and Smallpox, to the fantasy diseases like Pirate Plague and spreading Christmas Joy, and myriads of others. And, if that weren't enough to keep you busy with the 142 achievements, they have included a workshop, so you can download community made scenarios and/or create and share your own.

High Strategy:
The premise is simple enough. You create a new disease and your goal is to watch it spread around the world. Naturally, since it is a game, you can't win by simply covering continents. You must wipe out humanity for a victory. You are able to name your disease, and choose the genetic traits, as well as the symptoms and the transmission traits for spreading the disease, whether it is something that spreads from insects, birds, by air, or sea... etc. Then, as humanity fights for a cure, you try to stop the cure before you've covered the planet.

Die-Hard Fan:
I originally reviewed the game in early access. The game has gone through many updates, and since then I was able to participate in the alpha and beta testing phases for multiplayer, which was added to the game along with the full release. So, I've updated this review to reflect all changes.

The game has given me more than 150 hours of fun in early release, and now with over 300 hours in-game, I am still exploring all the fun and challenging levels. When I first started exploring this fascinating game, I found I was able to beat the Virus and Bacteria easily; finishing off both in one play-through each. But, I found the Fungus Disease and the Black Death scenario both to be very difficult to spread before they were cured by Scientists. But, they all are accomplished with time. The game definitely contributes to obsessive personality traits, like repeated hand-washing, and 12 hour gaming sessions.

I managed to turn the Earth into a 'Planet of the Apes' with my own Simian Flu on the 2nd try. The first time, I had tried to develop the rampage gene. It didn't spread far before the humans managed to develop a cure. Too aggressive! So, I slowed it down a bit, and worked on the Simian side of the coin; developing colonies of apes, and making it spread among them, while increasing their intelligence. When the Earth was covered, I added deadly symptoms to finish it off with one quarter of the ape population surviving the human drone attacks, which were colossal-scale.

Narrative:
The game is imaginative and rich in story, not-surprisingly since plague is the story of civilization. The main game plays out on a world map. If you watch the news bits, and little popups, you see that some countries begin to execute and/or bomb whole cities of the infected, out of hysteria and fear. The disease spreads in real-time, as you are making changes in the control panel to try to counter-balance the reactions of the humans to your disease. But, there are speed and pause buttons for those who want to control the action. Also, in the single-player, opening up map and disease screens automatically pauses the game so you can get back to bursting dna bubbles when you are finished making changes.

I've already decided that Greenland is the place to go in the case of world contageon. They are so isolated that many games are lost simply because Greenland closes their ports to prevent the plague spreading.

Graphics & Sound:
The graphics are first-rate; utilizing a variety of color and fx cues to help you monitor the situation as it develops. The different countries are covered with the color of your disease, and then turn to black as the humans there all die. The control windows are amply stocked with a variety of graphs and charts to analyze your disease's progress, and at game's end, to analyze why you won or lost. The music is intense and dramatic. Different sound bits include children singling Ring Aaround the Roses" which was a children's song from the Middle ages about the Bubonic Plague.

Multiplayer:
You can choose games with friends
recommended: co-op or versus mode. Leader boards let you know how your opponent ranks. The multiplayer community is already spreading and many more are dying for a chance to win the co-op brutal achievement. These achievements
hoursPlayed: though easy to obtain if you have a good working partnership
voteText:
would probably be more difficult if you don't chat or talk to the other player to coordinate. You can't play "by the seat of your pants" here. It takes team-work.

Pros:
*High Strategy and realistic simulation gaming at it's finest
*Multiplayer Vs. & Co-op
*Extreme Replay Factor
*High level of control-The element of choice makes you feel like a Superman in game. When you make small changes
helpfulPercent: big things happen.\n*Friendship forming- You will develop close partnerships in the multiplayer co-op
votesHelpful:
because you won't win otherwise.

Cons:
*You will not finish this game in under 100 hours. My testing buddy 100% it in under 200 hours
votesTotal: even with all the beta testing hours. I'm not finished yet.\n*Though guides are certainly helpful
votesFunny: having a list of steps won't guarantee success because your timing and decisions effect results.\n\nVerdict: Plague Inc is an awesome game that makes the scientific/academic investigation humorous.  You get to enjoy what would seem on the one hand an evil and diabolic plot to exterminate the world
commentsCount: and on the other a biology experiment. I highly recommend this game for everyone above age 12. I rate this RTS game a 10 out of 10."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, a game where you spread a disease to end all human life... what's not to love! So many plagues and gene types to unlock and use. So many possibilities. When I first played this game, I instantly fell in love with it. There are many positive points about these games.

+ Replay value

A lot of replay value. I could be playing this for years and would not get bored of it. Especially with the Steam Workshop Integration. Tons of custom scenarios created by people all over the world. Endless fun.

+ Educational value

Now, the part no one's been waiting for. This game does give some educational value. People get to learn different types of plagues and symptoms. Very educational. Okay, done with this part. Whew.

+ Scenario Creator

Why go with the normal boring symptoms, transmissions and abilities when you can completely change them to whatever your heart desires. The scenario creator provides players a chance to carve the world to their own liking. Renaming countries, setting your own government actions, creating non-existent diseases and more. Plague Inc can't get any better than this.

I would add in some negative points, but I couldn't find any. Oh well :)

Plague Inc is a very addictive, innovative and smart game. Even in Early Access is this game a big success. A few bugs here and there, but it's still developing. I can tell that this game is going to skyrocket once it is fully developed. Can't wait for multiplayer! Plague Inc is here to stay!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Plague Inc: Evolved is the PC version of the game Plague Inc, which was released for the tablet/smartphone in 2012. Updated frequently, Plague Inc: Evolved is a Strategy and Simulation game where you control a plague in an effort to wipe out mankind. You can evolve, and devolve one of several, plagues, viruses, and worms, in your quest to destroy the world. There are multiple game modes which have their own strengths and weaknesses and require different strategies to win. Converting the world into Zombies with the Necroa Virus, or Enslaving the human race with the Neurax Worm are just Two examples of the variety Plague Inc: Evolved offers.

Recently Plague Inc: Evolved released a 1v1 multiplayer mode, where you can play against others. This mode offers different options than the single player modes and can be a lot of fun. There are so many different ways you can go about playing this game, it can become quite addictive. I would recommend if you enjoyed the App version to get this game for the PC as you will not be disappointed. If you are new to the game, and enjoy killing or enslaving billions of people, this game would be right up your alley. Plague Inc: Evolved is a value buy!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a huge fan of the Android game it was a no brainer for me to pick this up when it went on sale, certainly not disappointed. In Plague Inc: Evolved your aim is to eradicate humanity using a disease of your creation. A strategy game at its core you will rely on some luck but finding an effective strategy for your disease is the key to success.

+Nice looking game
+3D view of your disease which reacts to evolution and devolution
+A good selection of pathogens to choose from
+A good number of modifiers unlocked by winning a match to make the game more interesting
+Some truly hilarious jokes, mainly about the gaming industry, including one about Valve and another about CoD
+Good level of difficulty on normal, you might not win on your first try
+Different enough from the iOS and android version to make it worth a buy but similar enough to be as good if not better
+The option to speed up time
+Doesn't feel like an early access game, everything you can play feels complete

+/-Reasonably frequent updates, better than most but not as frequent as others
+/-You only get unlocks on normal or higher difficulty
+/-Quite a laid back game, doesn't require much input

So far I haven't come across any negatives worth noting

Verdict:
9

A great game with a lot of potential, if you aren't ready to give up your money then this is certainly one to watch.

El K.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The simple question everyone wants to have answered: Is this game worth buying?
The answer is >>> NO <<< .

First of all, it's the port of a 0,99€ phone app. Charging 14€ for that seems preeeeetty harsh to me. But hey, maybe it's actually worth the money?

The game is an advanced version of the old Flashgame Pandemic II, which was a great game of it's time and I truly enjoyed playing it. Actually, that's the only reason I decided to get Plague Inc anyways. Now, Plague inc is a bit more advanced then Pandemic, no doubt. The mutations system ismore complex, the graphics and algorythms much superb...
But it doesn't add much else.Once you figured out the basic route, the game is literallyjust clickclickclick-wait-win. Every single time. The different plague types only change that at a minimal level.

Look at my game time. I havejust finished the game, unlocking the cheat plagues (those giving you godmode anti-cure or unlimited evolution points). How? Just by doing the same thing a dozen times over again, with every plague the game offered.
And that's it. And they charge 14€ for that.

Now, a big point for me was the Multiplayer mode. I could really see potential replayability value there...
BUT it's not even remotely implemented yet.


So, my resume: Great concept (duh, they imported it from a great and innovative old game). Fun gameplay. But ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ repetitive and no further content to keep you playing. In it's current state, 2-3€ sounds like a nice price. If they really go up ahead and add a GOOD multiplayer mode, I'll gladly change my review. But till then, don't buy this.


PS: Quick update:
They STILL didn't add the promised multiplayer, but instead keep throwing in 'more different plagues' that play usually exactly like any of the others, adding nothing new to the game.

PSPS: 6 months later, they ACTUALLY added a multiplayer. Albeit I feel trolled by the fact it's not the 'human vs virus' multiplayer I was actually hoping for.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Plague Inc Evolved allows you to release a virus somewhere on to the earth and spread it to other countries. The virus can do this by itself, with enough time (you will absolutely fail in the end), but you can also evolve it by upgrading several of the many upgrades. For example, you can let birds or other animals and rodents carry the virus to other places and countries, or you can make it less vulnerable to humid environments. The goal is to infect and kill every person on the earth, by all means necessary. And all of this is done in a very realistic way, and it's a blast to play, let me tell you.

One thing that should absolutely be fixed, though, is the fact that pop-ups (mostly for tutorials) pop up in EVERY SINGLE game you play. It's very annoying and there's no way to disable this (yet).
If you can ignore that little part of the game you will absolutely have fun with it.

Recommended !

[Rating: 85/100]

reviewText:
You know... this is a really fun game. Though the enjoyment you take may be a bit... questionable, I think?
I mean, you eradicate humanity with a disease. Trying to imagine how people would suffer from your creation would make you sick. Thankfully, all you see is world map and few other windows.

The difficulty the game provides is very flexible. Either go for a smooth killing spree or struggle with cure progress.
This game also features A LOT of upgrades for each disease (there are quite many of them which you can unlock).

Come to think about it, it's a strategy game. You start somewhere and expand until you take over the world. Or in that case, kill everyone (though it's not always necessary).

There is also a multiplayer mode. Both versus and co-op are fun to play and can give you quite a challenge.

I'm not really sure what else I should write about this game. Maybe workshop support? Millions of custom scenarios and an editor to make your own? Yeah, I guess I should mention that either. Oh wait, I just did. Anyway, that's all I can say.

If you are into strategy games (or even if you aren't) and don't mind infecting the world, then go ahead and try it.

reviewText:
Lack of Common Sense has eradicated 99% of humanity.
11/10 - 100% accurate.
Somehow Greenland was immune, I'm now totally moving there.

Game Features: Greenland somehow surviving every apocalypse.
Being able to cause humanity to worship worms.
A multiplayer mode that allows Memes to fight for world domination.
What's not to love?

(Actual Review)
My personal impressions of the various modes after playing through most of the game.
Single player is more of a limited-resources strategy game with a bit of randomness and time constraints thrown in.
Versus Multiplayer is a Optimization war that's equal parts strategy and luck in your opponent's starting moves not countering yours.
Co-op MP seems like a somewhat harder and far more chaotic version of SP.
Scenarios are mostly the main part of SP with various modifiers thrown in, or recreating historical plagues.
The Tutorial is exactly what it should be.

Overall, I'd give the game a 9/10, mainly because SP mostly relies on Workshop support or achievement hunting for replayability, but there's enough content in the game to last quite a while without even touching MP, so it's not too big of a deal.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Really excellent game.
It's a simple plague simulation game that involves a lot of strategy to try to infect and destroy the world. The infection patterns are quite realistic. To start off, the plagues are fairly simple bacteria, but you unlock crazy plagues (allowing zombies, for example).
Games are pretty quick, running 10-30 minutes from my experience.
You can name your own plague, creating many hilarious phrases to pop up during the game. Stick to singular nouns or proper names and you will get some amazing combinations.

For anyone worried about it being early access, there is more than enough content to keep you busy for a very long time. If the creators hadn't told me it was unfinished, I wouldn't have known. I still look forward to updates (which the developpers are keeping up with), but it's not an incomplete game without them.

On a science note, the only real problem I have with this game is how mutations occur in all the Plague cells at once. In actuality, a mutation would only occur in one instance and then have to spread again from the new patient 0. It makes the infect everyone then evolve deadly symptoms" tactic to lose some of the magic."

I don't understand why this game is still in Early Access. It's one of the most complete games I've played. Rather bug-free as well!

As for the price-tag, if you're planning to explore the game to it's fullest, i.e.: do all or most of the achievements, you can spend a LOT of time with it. I spent about 50 hours in game (counter shows more but idle and so on..) and that's about how long it took me to do all of the achievements. And these get really hard in the end! But it adds to the fun for me. For people who are uncertain as to if this game's worth the money, I recommend just trying out the phone version. Yeah, the content on the mobile version is largely the same, but due to the nature of touchscreens and the capability of phones, it's rather dull on phone - I feel. Sometimes you just lack the tempo to do certain tasks in a certain speed on touch, while on PC it's much easier with all the hotkey and mouse controls. It's simply more manageable. reviewText:
Early Access Review

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Differences between this and the mobile version:

- Better Music
- Better Graphics
- No microtransactions (unlock everything just by playing)
- Scenario editor (you can make your own scenarios and play user made scenarios [you can wipe out humanity with fridges!])
- The freshly added Multiplayer
- The upcoming Co-op mode

Is it worth it?
- Yes!

In this game you choose between different plague types to wipe out humainty.

While certainly not easy (mostly because there's no tutorial, but since it's early access it will be added in the future) it is rewarding for a while once you know the drill (mostly because it's almost the same tactic for every plague type). There are also 3 special plagues (neurax worm, necroa virus, simian flu) that require different tactics. You'll unlock genes for every win to modify your plague. After that, you can try to beat the game on Mega Brutal.

Then you move on to scenarios. They are different from the normal game and therefore you still have to put thought in your actions. After that you basically have seen everything from singleplayer. Now you can play some custom made scenarios.

It's time for the Multiplayer! You have to either infect 100% of the world population or have the other plague getting wiped out by making humanity focus on the cure for the other plague or kill all it's hosts (passively or actively). More modes are coming.
Every game of multiplayer is different, because the enemy has different tactics (unlike in singleplayer). You'll have to adapt and use their mistakes to your advantage to win. There are special transmissions, symptoms and abilities just for multiplayer.

I can't write about the co-op mode because it's not out yet.

9/10 because early access

If you don't like it right now, wait until it's out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In Plague Inc: Evolved, Your goal is to wipe out the human race with a type of epidemic. The game pretty much speaks for itself. Though the game sometime feels like it is designed for smartphones, it is very fun nonetheless.
NO SPOILERS AHEAD.

Pros:
The Idea of Plague Inc is very unique and the concept is very nice.
The Gameplay is fun and addictive.
The Variety between the types of plagues is good.
The Zombie and Planet of the Apes Plagues are a ton of fun to play with.
The Atmosphere at the end of the game is very chilling. As the last humans are dying, everything on Earth stops which can give you such an erie feeling.
The Steam Workshop makes this game 10 times better. User Created plagues with custom timelines and traits are very awesome.

Not Sure:
I don't like clicking on my screen every couple of seconds to catch the bubbles. This clearly is a mobile mechanic in which you need to keep clicking on your screen. When you level up, eventually there is a gene which automatically pops the bubbles for you which a must have.

Cons:
The Game does get repetitve after you figure out the formula for the game which doesn't take that long.
Many major countries are missing from the map.

Final Verdict:
Overall, Plague Inc: Evolved is a very nice game. Though it does get repetitve after a while, there is plenty of fun to be had playing this game.
I give Plague Inc. Evolved an 8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTE: THIS REVIEW IS NOT MY FINAL THOUGHTS OF THE GAME. IF MY OPINION CHANGES DRASTICALLY OR WHENEVER THE GAME IS RELEASED FROM EARLY ACCESS, I WILL REWRITE THIS REVIEW.

Do you or have you ever despised humanity? Do you like video games but you're tired of the same old shoot em ups? Do you want something (fairly) new and unique? Well, my friend, this is the right game for you!

Create a disease from a variety of disease types (which you have to unlock... fun), select special traits for your disease (also unlocked... more fun), select your difficulty, and infect Patient Zero. You then choose some skills to evolve your plague to make it more lethal, easier to infect others, or resist outside forces (i.e. temperature and drugs). Unfortunately the governments of the countries aren't very keen on the idea of you eliminating the human race, so they'll shut borders, airports and harbors and try to cure your disease, so you'll have to race against the clock to infect the world and evolve enough lethal symptoms to kill the world. Rinse and repeat.

The gameplay is fun, there is a bit of strategy on choosing which country to infect, whether you want to be able to infect by air or water first or if you want to invest some points to get bonus infectivity in colder countries. More strategy comes when you get traits for your disease, since they add bonuses to infectivity, extra DNA points, and a couple more nifty abilities. Each disease has some varying traits, like virus evolving frequently, biodisease being so deadly you have to suppress the lethality, nano-virus being built in with a kill switch that you must race against, and there are much more. It's worth it to unlock the diseases, since some of the cooler ones like Neurax Worm (mindcontrol) and Necroa Virus (zombies) are unlocked a bit later and it's always fun to mess around with those. There are also random events that happen that will affect the game, making each experience different.

The display looks nice and it's easy enough to see what's going on. There's a cool little body chart that shows you where in the human body your disease affects. You can see what's going on in all countries, how they're combating your plague, how their cure research is coming along, and if the government is still stable there or if it's falling apart.

There are also scenarios where you mess around with stuff, mostly stuff like little to none plane transmission, a mirror version of Earth where all of the countries characteristics are reversed, a virus that's DNA is damaged, affecting its transmission, and some more. Steam Workshop also makes an appearance, letting you create your own scenario. The communuty for this game is pretty large and I can see multiplayer being popular when the dev releases it.

There are some problems I had with the game, most of them small however. Mostly minor stuff like Portugal being part of Spain, Alaska being part of Canada (to be fair, the dev makes fun of this in an event so I dont care about that :P), Hawaii being nowhere to be seen yet, minor stuff like that. I can see this game becoming a bit repetetive, but it hasn't become that for me yet. One thing I would like to see, though, are different... I guess maps, you'd call them. Stuff like the continental USA with all of the states instead of the whole world, the providences of Canada, a map where the melting of the ice caps has flooded the world, stuff like that. That would make the game more replayable.

Regardless of any criticisms I may have, Plague Inc Evolved is a breath of fresh air with plenty to offer and more to come. 9/10. Never has a game made me hate a country for no good reason like this one has. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Greenland... Anyway, get this game now. It's worth it even at the full $15 or your regional equivelant. Just know that this is an Early Access game, so the game isn't complete yet. However the dev updates frequently, so it could be coming out of Early Access soon. Either way, though, it's worth getting. So get it. NOW!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

tldr:
To be honest, the pricetag is the main reason I'm giving thumbs down. Otherwise, the game meets its own goal but I can't recommend it since it's painfully static and repetitive. I spent 2 hours playing it but it felt more like 20...

Too long part
The game has very fascinating background and it's very exciting to discover everything it has to offer at first. But as you go on, you realise that while the content is wide, it's also quite shallow. You basically spend your time staring at a world map and some pulsing red dots progressively expanding over time.

There are also red, orange and blue bubbles to pop every now and then, which in all honestly seems like a very very desperate attempt to make the gameplay look more dynamic. I imagine this whole concept works amazingly on mobile devices but it's just not good enough on a PC.

Another way to spice things up is various events which occur in a more or less random fashion. Most of these are opportunities which can be abused to spread your disease faster. Problem is that these events tend to happen on the other side of the globe and you don't have enough resources to react in time.

I also feel like there is a huge gap in the difficulty levels, as Normal can basically be beaten by not actively doing anything at all while Brutal seems almost impossible in comparison. If humanity starts working on a cure and you havent infected every single person on the planet yet, you basically lost the game because you usually don't have enough resources to deal with the cure development and security precautions. At Brutal and Mega Brutal difficulties the discovery feels very random which is what makes it so hard and infuriating.

Fun thing to note is that island countries become impenetrable fortresses once the cure development starts and you haven't infected anyone in there yet.

reviewText:
*artwork/animation: (10/10)
For what the game is, there's not a whole lot of demand for an exceptionally rich animation. That being said, I think the devs did such a great job with creating the atmosphere for this game with how the game is visually displayed. I played this game way back when there were only a few different game modes and I have enjoyed watching this game develop and progress the way it has. On the preview screen where you can pick your disease type (aka: game mode) they give you a preview of what the virus actually looks like. I think this is such a simple touch but it adds so much to the game. It won't leave you wondering what in the world a prion looks like haha. They show you the diseases being transmitted and they show you how many people are dying and becoming infected. They show you pictures of the world becoming devastated. It's really cool and simple.

*Sound: (10/10)
Again I have nothing really to complain about or to critic on for this section. They add music which creates the atmosphere for the game, they add sound effects for when you collect points, when people start becoming infected, when they develop a cough you hear people coughing; it's really subtle though, don't worry. Plus half the time you're too busy wondering what your next move should be to even listen to the background noise but with out it, would this game be the same?

Hours to complete: (10/10)
This varies. It depends on how long it takes you to infect everyone, how long it takes you to kill everyone, how long it takes you to read through all the transmition options and abilities as well as learn them. How many different times you had to retry to beat the disease, etc. However, you can get so much play time from this game. Not only are there 10 different disease types to chose from, there's also 4 different difficulties for each one. Not to mention the 139 different achievements there are.

Story line: (10/10)
It's pretty self explanatory. You're controlling a disease to devastate and kill off humanity. That's literally it. I will give it originality points for sure.

Gameplay: (6/10)
What? You didn't really expect me to give this game all 10/10 did you?? No matter how much I love all the little details and everything in the game the most important section is the gameplay of course. So let's start off with how this game works. You pick your disease, you name it, you pick where in the world you want your disease to start infecting, you wait for DNA points (this is how you upgrade your disease) you select how you want it to transmit, you select how you want it evolve, you wait for everyone to become infected, you resist their cure efforts, you select your symptoms, you wait for everyone to die, game over you win. On to the next disease type. This is literally the entire game. Now there are a few different disease types that do follow a different order in order to beat it, for example, the necroa virus. (aka: zombies) but for the most part, you're following the exact pattern I just listed above. Don't get me wrong, it's a fun game and there's a lot of customization involved, but will you be playing this game for 6 hours straight? Probably not. You'll most likely get bored of the repetition with in the first few hours. That being said though, it is a nice game to have if you're bored with the other games you have and need a nice little break from them. Or for procrastinating like I am at the moment.

Price: (7/10)
$14.99 currently.
The price is meh. You get all the customization, all the achievements, all the unlimited hours of game play, etc etc. But why it hasn't fully sold me for this price is only based on the fact that I can't find my self playing this for hours straight. I don't want to pay $15 for a game I'll get bored of within 2 hours and have to come back to later you know? If that doesn't bother you then go for it, if it does, grab it when it's on sale.

Overall:
I love this game and have for years.
I would recommend this game to people who like:
> World domination
> Achievements
> Customization options
> Casual games

reviewText:
The novelty of this game has been slightly tainted, in my opinion, due to having played some 100 hours in class since its Android release.

Nevertheless, it's a pretty solid port - you could say it's close to a different game because of all the new features, like Scenario Editor and Co-op/VS Multiplayer. All of them are really nice additions that (with the exception of VS Multiplayer, arguably) help boost the game's longevity, the same way new disease types have done for the mobile version.

For the most part, you're gonna be staring at one of three screens: the map screen (showing the disease spread), the disease screen (where you can purchase traits with accumulated DNA), and the world information screen (showing the measures being taken against your disease as well as progress towards human extinction). Anything you can think of is shown, even as graphs detailing your statistical growth, the percentage of population infected and dead, and the cure research conducted and needed.

A little thing that's making it more enjoyable to play through is just reading through the symptoms and trying to imagine what unholy suffering I'm causing to the humans, slowly appearing on the map as darkening red dots that stop shuffling about as they poop out their organs. Talk about being morbid and sadistic.

The price tag may put you off, especially if you've played the original mobile versions and/or find the additions potentially unnecessary. Just to be sure, grab it on a sale, and let your inner mad scientist free. A million is a statistic after all. Or perhaps 7 billion even.

Great fun game. A massive improvement over the mobile game, and I've never once experienced a bug or problem, considering it's in early access.

The steam workshop is an amazing idea, you can download other people's disease types, or upload your own to the workshop.

I've got a fair amount of hours on this game, although about 11 of these are trying to complete the Necroa Virus... it's not easy ;)
And a multilayer mode is also in development!

All in all, I'd give it a 9.5 / 10.

reviewText:
This is a difficult review, I'm really struggling against the simple 'recommend/don't recommend' system.  Like many people I played this game originally on my cellphone and found it to be quite entertaining.  The whole game is here and I really have nothing against it or it's strategy.  Heck, it's one of the few mobile games I liked because it actually fit the medium it was made for.  And yet, that's the core of why I cannot recommend it:

The game was better on mobile.  This experience is built for a touch screen.  The point and click gameplay it utilizes is clunky on my HD display where the menus feel too large, unfocused and under utilized.  The interaction with your virus was highly detached on a small screen, you were an observer as you tinkered with it's evolution.  The 'pimple popping' made sense with touch but it feels like substitute gameplay with a mouse.  The simple evolution of your virus made sense on the bus but it feels like substitute gameplay at my desk.  Perhaps it is because I knew it as a time-wasting mobile game and that is exactly the type of experience I don't want when I put down my phone.  Perhaps it's why AdVenture Capitalist is fun on the go, but I have no urge to play on Steam.

Then again, you ~can~ play it on a cellphone or tablet still and get the 'authentic' experience.  This may not be the worst port of a cellphone game to the PC but at the same time it's just not any better.  The pick up and play is gone.  The swift menu navigation is gone.  And the pop-ups which somehow didn't bother me on mobile are positively aggravating here, it's like an endless flood of tutorial messages.  It's good for a few minutes of your time but it's just better where it originated: in the palm of your hand.  All the gameplay which fit the mobile genre well feels like a wasted concept and for ten dollars you could easily buy something far more interesting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay I might as well throw a review out there.

This game is solid as a time waster, in a very satisfying and yet, incredibly challenging way. You can approach the game in a very simple mindset and have fun with it, or try to approach it tactically and find challenge in the many different ways to play each type of disease. The interface is very simplistic and some of the notifications have some witty humor to them, along side the satire news banner.

Some of the best fun is naming your disease something utterly stupid, so you can laugh to yourself reading the pop-ups.

The game has four difficulties, and a wide varieties of diseases each one can be developed differently for different victories. In addition to the many different countries and locations to start, each one will provide different challenges for your disease. Casual and Normal difficulty are pretty much for the average player, with normal providing some good challenge. Then the game ramps up to Brutal and the dreaded Mega Brutal in which disease seems impossible.

Your goal is simply regardless of how you choose to play. Destroy humanity. Infect everyone and increase your diseases lethal level till no survivors remain. The shorter number of days it takes you to wipe out humanity, and the smaller percentage of the cure determines a scoring system.

The music also sets the tone very well, and in some disease missions the music is slightly altered. The sound effects are simple but excellent for a title like this.

For only $15, this game has plenty of replay value and is a ton of fun.

Have you ever wondered how a zombie-virus would go about starting the apocalypse?
Have you ever wanted to kill all humans?

The game creates it's ambience with a pulsing (but rather dull) soundtrack and flavor text of world-events that actually do influence the game's progression.

It's especially fun on mobile devices and is also available for Android.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Plague Inc. EVOLVED is a virus simulation where you name and create your virus, pick a host country, evolve, mutate and spread across the world until you've infected and killed every person on earth.

Choose from a variety of symptoms and abilities for your virus to strategically spread and infect new countries while the remaining healthy population closes borders and works towards a cure. Unlock new abilities and infections by wiping out the human race, and add a bunch of awesome, well-made scenarios via the workshop.

+ Simple interface and menus
+ Comical achievements, and lots of them
+ Variable gameplay speed makes for quick games
+ Different strategies required for spreading your virus from game to game
+ Symptom tree makes for some interesting, humorous, and sometimes dark combinations
+ Impressive workshop content adds a ton to the game
++ Multiplayer update for versus or co-op viral action*

- Point and click point gathering system is meh

Free multiplayer update and awesome workshop support make this a no-brainer*. Oh, and if a viral apocalypse ever really goes down, your best bet is to head for Greenland before they close the ports.


8.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

http://youtu.be/2K3DhlcAJF4

You may be saying to yourself 'hey I've seen this game before' and you would be correct in that assumption. Plague inc was originally an iOS and android game and has now come to PC via Steam early access. Now you no doubt know what the game is all about so the purpose of this video is to inform you whether it's worth your hard earned cash.

Developed by one-man developer Ndemic Creations and released originally for mobile devices in 2012 Plague inc went on to be the 15th most downloaded paid iPhone game of 2012 in the U.S. (and 18th on iPad). In March 2013, the game went on to win multiple categories of the Pocket Gamer Awards, including Overall Game of the Year.

The game itself is a plague simulator, the object of the game is to infect and kill the entire world's population. Once you have selected what type of plague your going to use, be it bacteria, parasite or a myriad of other options. You then go on to select where you plague will start by selecting a country of your choice. Throughout the lifespan of your plague you can evolve it, not only increasing its infectiousness but also it's lethality. You accomplish this by purchasing various so called evolutions with DNA points. DNA points are earned naturally by the plague spreading but also by clicking the DNA and infection bubbles that pop up on the world map as the plague spreads.

As your plague spreads and starts causing fatalities, authorities will start to take notice. At a certain point scientists will begin to research a cure for your plague and then the race begins to see if you can kill the populace before a cure is developed. You can hamper the cure research progress by popping the research bubbles on the main map and by also purchasing evolutions that hamper research development.

I really enjoying Plague inc on my iOS device last year, I thought it was a fun little title that had some replayablity but it certainly was not a core game. So it begs the question is this title worth $15 of your hard earned cash? And before the complainers out there say, well you can't critique an early access title, I'll say this, if your asking money for a product, I'm damn well going to find out if it's worth the money for people or not.

In its current state on early access, it is not worth your money especially since only the main game, which I might add is the same version as the mobile game, is available. Why spend $15 dollars on something that you can pick up for less the $3 on your mobile device. That being said there are some new features coming to the game like multiplayer, speed run mode and scenarios but even then will it be worth it?

For me personally, to make the $15 really worth it, this game will have to produce a great multiplayer experience. The multiplayer needs to add what the single player experience lacks, re-playability. While the cooperative and competitive multiplayer modes do sound like fun, I do doubt it will hold people for long. I think the single player could have done will some rework too, if it was me, I would have added some micro gameplay elements in there to add to the experience. Everything in the game is on the macro level, I would have added in some new levels. For example like in spore where you start of as a cell and as you grow the level gets bigger, what you could have done here is start of in a town of a country, the aim would be first to spread your plague across the country, then the game would go onto the world level.

I really feel that small changes like the addition of levels would have really added to the game and make spending $15 for what is essentially a mobile game, a more justifiable purchase. I'm not saying that Plague inc is a bad game, on the contrary its a very fun, if not superficial simulator. I simply feel that in its current state it is not worth $15 of your money, once the additional features are added especially the multiplayer, it may be worth another look. But for the time being, I'd wait either until full release or if your just interested in the single player, pick it up on your mobile device.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a realistic and simple disease simulator with a huge amount of options while keeping it simple and player friendly.

Pros
You can choose one among several disease types (bacteria, virus, fungus, parasite, prion, nano-virus, bio-weapon, neurax worm, necroa virus, simian flu and more may be add in the future)
You can name your plague
You can choose your plague's genetic code (initial traits)
You can choose on which country your plague will start from
You can evolve your plague with symptoms, abilities and type of transmission
The game has 4 difficulty levels being casual, normal, brutal and mega brutal they highest the difficulty the more realistic and challenging the game becomes
A lot of information is displayed about world events and how the world is reacting to your plague and you can use the evolution system to evolve you plague making the best use of the events happening to help spread your pathogen
Aside from the main game disease types there are official scenarios with interesting diseases to play like black beath, smallpox and much more
There are also unofficial scenarios that are made by the players themselves and uploaded on steam workshop making the game have even more content
The controls are simple you can basically play using mouse only or mouse plus space (pause), 1, 2 and 3 to control game speed plus q (opens abilities, symptons, transmission tabs) and e (stats tab)
Cons
Can't think of any
If you like simulation games this is definitely a must buy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Despite this game being a simulation of a disease, it's got alot more strategy than you'd initially think. Hence it being in my Strategy games library category.

Basically what you've got here is an experience akin to the mobile android game Plague Inc. Only awesomely enough it's the same cost as all the DLC for that game combined.
Plus looking at the prospect of Co-op and even Competitive Multiplayer, Custom Scenarios (likely implemented via the workshop) and the existence of Speed Runs, a Leaderboard, and even a virus not currently featured in Plague Inc. The Simian Virus as a reference to the Planet of The Apes series.

You start with Bacteria, Then Virus, and later control Fungus, prion and even my favorite and one of THE EASIEST plague types in the game, The Neurax Worm, a plague that is essentially a brain worm (Alpha Centauri's Mind Worms, anyone? :D) tha can either kill or mind-control, allowing for a second victory alternative.

Whichever plague you start with, the object of the game is to kill all of mankind, save for the Neurax Worm which can turn all of humanity into a slave race (which in my opinion is better than killing them all).

There are 7 plague types, and they all play differently, although a couple feel or act similar, no single plague works the same as another, which is the important part as nobody wants to play an FPS where 60% of the guns all act the same, or an RTS where 5 units are literally the same thing with a paint job.

There is easily a wealth of content as the game itself is fairly tricky with plague types like the Necroa Virus, a plague that can turn people into zombies.... or just act like a normal plague... which doesn't work as well as when a zombie, you have abilities you can use.

If you oppose Evolution, or find killing humanity in a simulation wrong somehow, or you don't like Simulations or Strategy games... Then this game isn't for you.

Otherwise, if you're okay about either point, or like any of them, then I highly encourage you to get a copy of this game, It's loads of fun, allowing for more than 6-24 hours worth of gameplay if ignoring the achievements.
To get them, I'd imagine that number would triple easily.

This game's a blast, I personally see it as a 7/10 in it's current state, it may easily rise in the future as I just cannot forget future features like Co-op, which I am absolutely ecstatic about.

So yeah. 7/10, once leaving Early access, I will come back and redo this review.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Score: 7.5/10
Total playtime: 31 hours
Price: $10 or less

Plague Inc. A game of creating and evolving various types of illness to wipeout mankind. Be it bacteria, virus, parasite, zombies, simian ape flu (Planet of the Apes), nanomachine or a man made biological death virus you are tasked with infecting and ultimately wiping out humanity. Transmission, Symptom and Ability are the three areas you will dabble in making your virus hardier in different climates and against man made medicine and air / water filters. Symptoms tend to come in three areas as well. Infectivity, severity and lethality. The trick is to keep infectivity high while keeping severity and lethality low initally. Should the latter two get too high countries will begin researching a cure for your illness.

While essentially the exact same game as the mobile app, the real fun comes from the Steam Workshop. Everything from demonic possession, the four horsemen of the apocalypse, Terminator-like machine uprisings, AI self awareness (I Have No Mouth and Must Scream), spider-based armaggedon, the 1982 'The Thing' and many more. Be it the coming of dragons, vampires, werewolves or transforming into a propane loving Hank Hill this game provides amusement with slight resource management and is well worth picking up on sale as a time killer.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Had my eye on this game for a while and was tempted when it recently went on sale. At the same time, I also happened to be dealing with my 3rd week of mono symptoms. In a weird sort of way, looking up information about the virus actually inspired me to finally pick this up.

And I'm glad I did!

To summarize, this game is basically a simulation of the transmission and evolution of a disease. You control transmission methods, symptoms, and abilities with the object being killing everyone before a cure can be created.

Thinking about your decisions is crucial. Can't just kill off everyone immediately because it cannot spread. Cannot make it too passive because the cure will catch up to you. So, you have to find a balance.

While it may be a dark premise, which might put some off, the game is pretty solid. Hoping multiplayer is on its way soon.

Added bonus: You give your disease a name. So, have a giggle killing off the planet's inhabitants with Kindness"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is 'Early Access'? I thought 'Early Access' meant you had to put up with flaws and crashes and incompatibilities.

THIS GAME is polished, clean, and almost fully functional. This is one of the rare cases where you actually feel like you are getting your money's worth for a game that is unfinished. The game is fully playable. Sure, there are certain pieces not included, such as custom scenarios to play out, or new plague type, but we have already seen an update that includes some of that. If you enjoy the mobile and flash versions of this game, this much more refined desktop version is a great buy. Early Access or not.

Plague Inc: Evolved is a simple concept. Take a disease and evolve it to the point where you can infect and eventually kill the entire human race. While the premise is simple, the tools given to you to accomplish this are vast. Multiple different 'bugs' to infect with (Bacteria, Virus ... Bio-Weapon, Mind Worms....) and many paths of evolution give this casual game huge replay value.

For those familiar with the simpler versions, here, the graphics are a bit more refined, easier to look at, but with no serious changes in design. Mostly you are presented with a simple World relief map, an interface by which you can evolve your plague, and an information screen regarding the World's progress to fight you or more information regarding those countries your are so desperately trying to infect. Simplistic perhaps, but it is all that is needed.

The audio soundtrack isn't going to win any awards, but instead provides the creepy horror movie ambiance that infecting the world with a nano-virus that spreads through open oozing sores, causing folks to have trouble concentrating and suffer narcolepsy, full system failure, and death, should have. Creepy hospital noises, disembodied coughs and fear abound.

Overall, I feel this is a great buy. You have a fully playable, fun game for a good price. This game already has multiple difficulties, types of plagues, and lots of replay. Plague Inc: Evolved is being updated regularly with new features at no extra cost. A few of the new features promise to add not only whole new ways of gameplay, but community support in the guise of scenarios designed and uploaded by your peers to play. Oh! Did i mention it supports cloud saves? Save your game at home, and play it on the road from your laptop!

If you are a fan of casual gameplay, and not a fan of the humans winning... then this is the game for you! So grab a pair of rubber gloves, slather yourself in some Purel, and let’s see what happens when a super bacteria escapes a lab in North Korea...

8/10

I'm looking forward for the future updates which may legitimate the price, but at the moment I feel the current price a bit expensive. I really hope that more plague types, game modes and evolutions will come which will further enhance the fun.

Overall I have enjoyed this game even in its current state and I can recommend it but only for those, who are into this genre.

reviewText:
Let's start of with saying, that I work in a hospital. Love taking care of all the people that are sick/dying and trying to fight off whatever illness/disease process they have.

SIck, I know! But look at it at a medical person's point of view: we have to know what disease it is and how it works to defeat it, but in this game, you have to make it BETTER!

If I'm a tumor, give me a chance to try and hijack the replication process of the cells to make it cancerous. I believe there are G-0 to G-3 gates during replication, but I'm not too sure right now as I write this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very enjoyable game!

Similar to the Flash game Pandemic (or Pandemic 2), if you have not played one of those and are interested in this game, I really do suggest to try them out first to get a feel for the type of gameplay.

Plague Inc is essentially a more refined version of Pandemic, with more features, more gameplay elements, more intersting evolutions, more more more!

Your task is simple; develop a pathogen to infect and kill the entire humankind. :)

There are many different ways to achieve this goal and each time you manage to complete it you unlock a new type of pathogen and a new gene which can be used the next time you play.

There are currently (24th June 2014) 9 different pathogens, for which you can select 5 gene slots, each slot has 5 different genes to choose from.
Genes are a way to get different starting stats on your pathogen, for example Darwinist" increases the chance of your plague mutating
date: "Aerocyte" increases chance of plague spreading by air. Your choice of pathogen and genes will affect your gameplay.\n\nThe challenge of the game is to try and beat the game with all kinds of pathogens
recommended: they have different types of mutations that you can research with some unique attributes and abilities.\n\nThe game is a tablet/mobile port
hoursPlayed: which is noticeable by some of the UI but in this type of game it isn't really an issue."

Simulator that allows you to eliminate humanity on Earth. You are a sickness the world has never seen before. You chose what symptom's will affect people, be it simple cough, headache, stomach problems, etc., how will it spread, through insects, animals, water, air, etc., where your origin country will be. What are your resistances to medicine and ability to withstand treatment. Keep one step ahead of humanity, while they try to eliminate you. Evolve, infect, multiply, kill.

Game is point and click based, with overview of the Earth, with all the countries, transport routes. You earn points by infecting more people, evolving yourself as a ultimate plague, stopping humanity from developing a cure and spending them on your evolution. It's a sick little simulation. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I can highly recommend this game. For those who are already familiar with the mobile version:

All additional content is or will be included but has to be unlocked during play. The visual presentation was adjusted for the PC and looks way better. The world map looks beautiful, and the country pages now include a textual description and camera surveillance. You get much more stats about how your plague is performing, and as a bonus, you can save and load your game at any time. Other gaming modes like speed run and campaigns will be added, but those seem to be added to the mobile version as well.

For those new to the game:

You get a quick to play, casual strategy game with an interesting theme and excellent visual presentation. On first glance, it may seem repetitive to just having to add perks until all humanity is wiped out. But the different plague types and random events require different strategies. It's quite rewarding when you succeed with your plague on the harder difficulty levels. As an additional challenge you can try to get the over 50 achievements, some of those are very interesting and require additional thought.

Pricing and Early Access:

I won't discuss the price as it is a personal choice of how much one wants to pay for a game. But compared to many other mobile ports, this one stands out because it was adjusted to PC standards and not just copied over. Also, for an early access game, it is quite stable and the basic gameplay is already there. I did not encounter any bugs, there are of course some very minor issues.

Summary:

If you are on the edge, and the price is ok, then buy it without any doubt. If it seems too expensive, then at least get and try the mobile version. There will be a steam sale eventually ;-)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I highly recommend this brilliant and addicting game that allows players to create their own viruses and bacteria. There are different levels of difficulty that give you a chance to get use to the mechanics and while there are still some issues like crashes (never in the middle of a game thus far, but sifting through options while running a dozen other programs), save files either hidden or acting a little funky (usually never need them personally) this game as it is right now is well worth the full price!

There is a slightly mildly steep learning curve but with the basics understood you'll find it obvious where you were getting it wrong. I really hope to see more cause it's another game that leaves you wanting more when all is said and done but has great replayability. A must buy imho.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my game of choice, when i have been playing other (more visually intense) FPS games.  Sometimes after playing a few hours or half a day, i really like to play a little longer, but my eyes will start to tear when trying to focus on moving targets while other players or objects keep moving around me...  Now i know i need a brake...

This game is relaxed on the eyes for the background (picture of earth, stretched to fit your square screen) is not changing !! Only things moving (appearing, not actually moving) are a few red dots that keep popping up to give you materials to work with. The game will allow for my eyes to rest..

Make no mistake !!  Just because the game is visually not very intense,,, it is every bit addictive, competetive and agitating if you fail yourself. The game revolves about your choices, your insights, your patience or lack off and the way you normally playgames. Get ready to be constantly challenged to learn, evolve and adapt. Time to think outside the box !!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Plague Inc pits you against the world, destroy or be destroyed in this all out battle of global proportions!

In this game you play the role of what I can only imagine is some psychotic mad-man evil scientist who has infiltrated the control room of the CDC. Your role from that point is to design the ultimate bioweapon and devistate the world. Prove you have what it takes to become the ultimate serial killer and spread you message through the world.

The aim of the game is simple, kill every last person in the world. This is achieved through a 4 step process:

1. Spread your pathogen to the far reaches of the globe.
2. Evolve" said pathogen to become the ultimate killing machine.
3. What as society crumbles and combines forces in a pointless attempt to stop your murderous rampage.
4. Profit?

Pros:
- Quite a few different types of bio killing things including viruses
hoursPlayed: diseases and so on.\n\n- Lots of upgrade paths to increase the severity of the
voteText: killing effectiveness and rate of transmission between the scumbag population of Earth.\n\n- Various elements of the game affect how your virus spreads

Cons:

Plague Inc Evolved is one of the coolest little simulators I have ever had the pleasure of playing.

The gameplay is simple, you pick a plague type, you buff it up, then you release it, and evolve it from there, the goal is even simpler, infect the world, and kill everyone.

The game offers plenty of viral types to play with, including fictional viruses like Zombie Plague, or the mind controlling Nurax Worm, and currently has a movie tie in with Planet of the Apes with Semian Flu, each with perks, and a diffrent approch to infection and the death of the human race.

This game is awesome and is more or  less compleate, the developers are just adding more content to the game, I highly recomend this game if you enjoy simulation games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a very good game... almost my top 5 favorites actually.

Won't lie, I got this for my best friend in real life. Didn't even have any interest for it at the time... however, due to the game's popularity and increased number of positive reviews, I purchased it for myself. Did not regret it in the slightest.

Unlike most strategy games, you REALLY have to consider how to indirectly make your virus (or disease) wipe out humanity. Every little choice matters, and can affect you in the long run. What I love about this game, is that humanity doesn't die easily even on, well, easy mode! They'll fight it till the end, and it's fun seeing who'll win. You or the world.

Every feature is unique, and I haven't seen a game like this in a long while. Everything that happens is recorded, you will get News of the latest events until your virus becomes deadly (or known) enough to make countries start worrying. It's realistic too since countries will start coming up with ways (news wise, or strategy wise) to stop your virus from killing everyone. It doesn't even stop there-

The more you unlock, the crazier (or creative) it becomes in you wiping out humanity. Extremely fun, plus the game is nice enough to let you speed things up since it can take awhile for the infection to spread country to country. Best way in taking any mode on is to make your virus spread quickly without hurting people (even a cough will make doctors eventually look into curing it.) Luckily you can devolve your virus's symptoms so that it doesn't end up drawing attention. Not to mention you can name your virus anything, and a LOT of events can occur in which your last run didn't activate. I somehow caused Japan to have a nuclear plant explode ... and that's just 1 out of the 103 events lol.

I give it a solid 9.5/10 and it's just in Alpha. I cannot wait till it's fully done. I also wonder how multiplayer will work?

reviewText:
This game is great. I've been playing on mobile for more than two years, and I must say that this version is more challenging. Since everyone has reviewed the single player, I am going to review the competitive side!

In vs mode, you are pitted against another (human!) player. You start out with un-modified bacteria, and you participate in games to unlock more stuff. One thing to remember is that tactics that worked on single-player may totally shaft you! For instance, all genes now have postives and negatives, and you may only use three at once! For plague types, there are currently three- your starter Bacteria, which has losts its ability; and two others unlocked at five victories: Virus and Bioweapon.

The gameplay itself is fairly simple- upon starting, everyone is given a short amount of time to find a country to settle down in. You may NOT both start in the same country! The starter phase is hide and seek. Depending on what country you started in, you start with different amounts of DNA. You also continue to get DNA bubbles... until you starting location has been found out. The other team then gets a boost in DNA. Note: Being a high-profile disease tends to work poorly in concealing your starting point. It is hard to see the other disease's locations at first.

For abilities and perks, they switched it around A LOT. Your stardard Air and Water traveling transmisisons are now teamed up with Dust (Arid) and Sweat (Humid). For symptoms, the previous symptoms are joined by 2 orange ones. These will unlock a tree that will either make the enemy plague's carriers easier to infect, or protect your own. Both are useful. Abilities has a serious overhaul. There is an ability that lets you fly planes to uninfected countries (like Trojan planes!), an ability that focuses cure research on your opponent in that area, and a buff that increases lethality and infectivity for BOTH diseases.

All in all, I would give the multiplayer an 8/10. It's not perfect, but it is extremely promising! I will look forward to Co-Op mode in the future!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played this game on my phone and I really liked it. I saw it's on the PC now so I had to buy this game. And I'm really glad I did. This is the full game, it has much more facilities and the graphics are really good.
What I think is really good about this game is that you have to play very strategically. If you evolve too fast people will die too quickly, but if you evolve to slow the cure will be finished before you've killed everyone. It looks like a simple game, but it's definitely not!
The extra content with Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is also really great! Taking the world over with apes, who doesn’t want to do that?! Playing this content you’re able to use more possibilities with evolving. The apes can use abilities to take down research labs and more.

It’s a really great game, especially for this price!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was a little reluctant to buy this as I can play Pandemic 2 for free as an online Flash game, but I'm glad I DID buy it!  Although it's Early Access, the main single-player campaign is fully playable and I've encountered no serious bugs at all (multiplayer and new single-player missions are now being worked on for later addition).  The game has taken care of all the irritations of the online Pandemic (where Madagascar would slam shut its borders as soon as anyone merely stubbed their toe, meaning game over), diseases can cross borders via birds and insects even when border controls are closed and there are more factors to meddle with in the hope of being evil and spreading your new disease before anyone has chance to notice and work on a cure.  Additionally, successful completions of the game unlock new bonus traits you can collect and use to develop your own mutations and improve your chances of winning.

The developers have made an excellent job of the game and I'm glad they brought it from app to PC.
