reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDefinitely worth the $15. If you've played this game on iOS or Android, skip this paragraph. Plague Inc is a world-ending virus simulator. It started out on iPhone a few years ago and was a huge success. It consistently topped app charts, had a number of really cool free updates, and it just gives you so much to do. The CDC even liked it enough to meet with the app creator and discuss how to make it more realistic! In this game, you control a plague (bacteria, virus, fungus, man-made plague, brain worm, and more...there's a lot to choose from). You choose where the virus begins, and you watch as it spreads across the world. You control what vectors the virus uses, how the virus defends itself against temperature and medicine, and what symptoms the virus produces (oh, and I'm just going to use virus" as shorthand for "plague" just because I'm more used to typing "virus"). There's a lot of strategy involved
date: whether you try to create a nearly invisible virus that
hoursPlayed: it will be too late or if you try to create a virus that becomes scarier and scarier as it spreads and just overwhelms cure efforts. The game has been balanced to really support both options. As you infect people
voteText: new countries
helpfulPercent: and kill people
votesHelpful: you gain DNA points that you use to alter your virus. The scarier that your virus is
votesTotal: the more you're rewarded with points
votesFunny: but the more that every scientist in the world focuses on curing you. Don't worry
commentsCount: however - the game does a great job of explaining everything to you. Whereas a game like Pandemic can be really intimidating with all of these different medical terms (even one for runny nose - are you kidding me?)
column16: Plague Inc prefers to use the common words for symptoms. You're not overloaded with choices (but there are enough for you) and the impact each DNA change has is clearly shown (such as infectivity
column17: lethality
column18: and how scary it appears to the world).\n\nFor those who have played it on mobile
column19: not much has really changed. Each plague is unlocked after beating the previous one
column23: it doesn't really look too polished as of yet. The UI feels outdated and inexplicably cheap. I almost feel like I'm playing a flash game in my browser. The UI is mostly functional
column24: but has a lot of empty space. It also has some elements that are just for show rather than solving a purpose. For example
column25: a bar graph to the right of the country status indicator (the main bar on the UI) has different colored bars that don't represent anything and don't move. I don't know why they're there. It's still early access
column27: every country has a picture of it (mostly just showing people and buildings
column28: maybe a landmark). The pictures look like cheap CGI (god knows why - there's no shortage of real pictures of locations)
column29: but there are maybe 10 - or less - pictures used for every country in the world. I don't mean that
column31: Sudan cycles through 10 pictures. I mean that Sudan
column34: and South Africa" (along with most of the rest of the continent) all have the same picture. Cheap CGI with nothing moving. At first I thought it was a neat touch
column35: but that kind of shallowness stands in contrast to how fleshed out the rest of the game is.\n\nOn the upside
column36: each plague type has its own 3D image that reacts as you upgrade it. It doesn't change as dramatically as the neurax worm on mobile
column37: but it will stretch out and rebound a bit when you upgrade it and wince when you devolve a feature. I think that's pretty neat
column38: and it doesn't feel as cheap. The DNA upgrade menu is definitely an improvement. Also
column39: the world status menu has been solidified and now has all of the important info on one screen. That's a huge improvement.\n\nAlso
column40: this game has Steam workshop integration
column41: meaning that people are submitting their own plague types. I saw one for a Hank Hill virus earlier today. It looks like people are going to have a lot of fun creating and customizing their own plagues
column42: and I think that's great!\n\nIn summation
column43: it's the same as the mobile game
column44: but with a new UI (with its ups and downs) and steam workshop support."

column31: there are different possibilities and they all depends on what pathogen you pick really.\n\nanother failure state which is very annoying is that some of the island nations (Greenland
column33: Caribbean) can actually escape infection by noticing the plague and closing off borders
column34: In my english video linked at the end of this review i have a situation where i wiped out the whole world and Greenland remained clean.\n\nto sum it up

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Plague Inc: Evolved is a game about a topic very near and dear to my heart: Big Pharma.

In Plagues Incorporated: Evolutions, you play an intrepid reporter looking to expose the lies of Big Pharma; you slowly uncover things like AIDS being created by the CIA and the flu vaccine actually causing autism. But, at every turn, you are persued by Big Pharma who work to discredit your work.

Like I said, I really enjoy Plaguez, LLC: Devolved because it covers a topic not many games do, and one that I have a personal stake in. You see, Big Pharma has set up a campaign to harass and discredit me at every turn; its gotten to the point where I can't even go outside without fear of someone shooting me with a tranq dart. I'm so glad that a popular game is finally increasing awareness of this important issue!

WAKE UP SHEEPLE/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I heard Plague Inc was moving from iOS to PC and sharpened my pitchfork. So tired of Steam being so cluttered with expensive mobile ports that make it hard to find actual games among them. Then I read the positive reviews, here. Put it in the back of my mind. Fine, maybe it's decent -- but I'm not paying full price for this. Maybe when it drops to five bucks for awhile, I'll try.

Something spurred me to make the impulsive move to eventually buy the game, anyway. And I played it. And . . . it was good. It was really good. Not perfect and lots of room for more compelling and complex additions, but . . . a really solid improvement over the old flash game or the iOS game. This is the way you need to think about making a port to PC. This is the attention and consideration that should be paid.

If you haven't played this type of game before, go check out the mobile version. If you like that, you're likely to enjoy this a lot, too. If you couldn't stand that, the PC version might not be for you. In other words, if you liked the original, this is more of that - and better.

Overall, $15 might still be a little pricey for this type of game. I think $10 would be ideal. It shouldn't be a deal breaker, though; if nothing else, put this on your list and come back to it when it's a little cheaper, if you are hesitant.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After 120 hours on the meter, I could say that this game offers a crazy amount of challenge even though it is supposed to be a casual game. Or is it? Maybe looks can deceive. First game I played when the game was on the fourth update on early access. They are adding features faster than I can learn to master them. If you think 40 hours of gameplay is worth 30-40 euros, then think how much worth of fun, and funny disappointments will you get for 13 euros.

Few headlines:
Gameplay - You work on three views. The main view is the whole planet, where you can zoom, and scroll, and so on. And you have to click points. Like in  Farmville, except the potatoes are human souls that you are about vanquish.

Music - Eerie. Gives my nightmares. Or maybe it is just filling enough for the mindset about to destroy the best and the worst of humankind.

Graphics - In progress. They are improving it all the time, and it fits the glove already.

Educational/Morals - Well. Heh. You are taking the role of a god, and pick on the dominant species on planet Earth. You still have a very good excuse: They started it first. And it might have some hidden educational value as well. About how diseases spread, how everything is interconnected, blaah blaah. Go kill the humanity.

Definitely 5/5.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game contains very few fancy pictures, models and sound effects. Instead, there are lots of numbers, trends, explicit and implicit parameters that have dramatic impact on gameplay. You will have to try it more than once to achieve understanding of how things flow in here.
But when you do that, it is experience nothing can compare with. Learning to act like disease, at some point you start feeling like disease and thinking like disease. It is a bit horrifying, but it is certainly exciting.
Dynamic, interesting, complex. Recommended for everyone who likes new experience and is not afraid of using brain while playing games, not relaxing it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Once, an app that started out on the IPhone, and went onto Android. I browsed on the Steam Store one day and found out that Plague Inc. moved onto PC.

The PC version is far different than the smart phone Appilication version. This version looks a lot better (since computers can handle MUCH more than just a smart phone) and feels more smooth. The concepts are about the same.

The PC version is a vast improvement since it's appilication version. Graphics have obviously improved. Some little things they've added onto the game really make a difference in setting this version from the app.

It's a lot easier to (if you're not good at geography) locate where countries are in the world menu. I'm very good at geography, so that was never a problem for me in the first place, but its a very nice addon. The diseases themselves have animations, and the water in the world menu has animations aswell, thus making the game look prettier. This game, like the app version, is very addicting.

Overall, this game deserves best, and even though it's currently in early access alpha, I still rate it a:

10/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Memes infected and killed all of humanity. 10/10 We all knew it was going to happen someday.

Theres a lot that can be said about this game but I'm going to keep this short and simple because frankly I think that the overwelming amount of positive reviews speaks for itself.

This game is one of those games where graphics mean virtually nothing. The whole point is to create an infectious disease or contagion that infects all of humanity and the kill them. It's absurdly simple sounding but it suprisingly takes a lot of skill in the higher difficulties. In fact this game rewards aggressive players, the only real restriction to playing this way though is balancing out lethality with infectivity since you need to infect faster than you kill.

The menu system pre-game is rather nice as it gives you options for pre-game modifiers to make your casual eradication of humanity a little bit easier. In game you have 3 major screens to pay attention to, your primary world map, the evolution screen and the overview. Theres little to no clutter in these screens making them easy to navigate and easy on the eyes. One recomendation I have though is to always make use of the pause time feature. It helps to plan out your next moves but keep in mind your evolution doesn't take effect until after the game is unpaused.

All in all I love this gae and am honestly suprised it's still listed as early access since it feels like a finished product. I highly recomend this game, easily worth the $15 price tag.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fun, Well developed and the most dynamic infection simulator out.

If it looks good to you get it, you will get what you expect and more.

If you are looking to destroy the world via a slow and painful death, this game is what you need and more. Originaly only hosting slightly different ways to murder the world with small alterations between disease types, there are now lots of different additions that really stood out to me and showed how good the developer(s) are working on this game. The two recent disease additions of the simian flu and the necroa virus (ZOMBIES) add a large dynamic to the game that not only is fun but shows the great potential for future diseases.

I also dabbled in multiplayer which is made to be very competitive and was happily surprised to see how different it was to single player. It really feels like you are against someone instead of just trying to be better than them with out them affecting you.

Also:
No microtransactions like the phone game... What is it? My birthday?!?

On the other side of the spectrum the game can feel repetitive with the vanilla diseases such as virus, bacteria, parasite.

For what it is at the moment I give it a 8/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Memes infected and killed all of humanity. 10/10 We all knew it was going to happen someday.

Theres a lot that can be said about this game but I'm going to keep this short and simple because frankly I think that the overwelming amount of positive reviews speaks for itself.

This game is one of those games where graphics mean virtually nothing. The whole point is to create an infectious disease or contagion that infects all of humanity and the kill them. It's absurdly simple sounding but it suprisingly takes a lot of skill in the higher difficulties. In fact this game rewards aggressive players, the only real restriction to playing this way though is balancing out lethality with infectivity since you need to infect faster than you kill.

The menu system pre-game is rather nice as it gives you options for pre-game modifiers to make your casual eradication of humanity a little bit easier. In game you have 3 major screens to pay attention to, your primary world map, the evolution screen and the overview. Theres little to no clutter in these screens making them easy to navigate and easy on the eyes. One recomendation I have though is to always make use of the pause time feature. It helps to plan out your next moves but keep in mind your evolution doesn't take effect until after the game is unpaused.

All in all I love this gae and am honestly suprised it's still listed as early access since it feels like a finished product. I highly recomend this game, easily worth the $15 price tag.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fun, Well developed and the most dynamic infection simulator out.

If it looks good to you get it, you will get what you expect and more.

If you are looking to destroy the world via a slow and painful death, this game is what you need and more. Originaly only hosting slightly different ways to murder the world with small alterations between disease types, there are now lots of different additions that really stood out to me and showed how good the developer(s) are working on this game. The two recent disease additions of the simian flu and the necroa virus (ZOMBIES) add a large dynamic to the game that not only is fun but shows the great potential for future diseases.

I also dabbled in multiplayer which is made to be very competitive and was happily surprised to see how different it was to single player. It really feels like you are against someone instead of just trying to be better than them with out them affecting you.

Also:
No microtransactions like the phone game... What is it? My birthday?!?

On the other side of the spectrum the game can feel repetitive with the vanilla diseases such as virus, bacteria, parasite.

For what it is at the moment I give it a 8/10.

reviewText:
How many times can someone destroy the world before it gets boring? I've successfully doomed the human race 50 times, and the game is still as fun as it was the first time. There are so many different diseases, genetic upgrades, and scenarios available that the game keeps fresh after dozens of iterations.

The co-op version is also a lot of fun, but it requires very good communication with your partner if you want to successfully obliterate mankind together.

Pro tip: watch out for the island nations. Iceland, Greenland, and New Zealand are the worst offenders, but Madagascar and the Caribbean have also proven problematic in the past. If you pull trigger too soon, those nations will spook, and close up their harbors, essentially locking you out of the country unless you get lucky with a mutation or special ability.

Oh and get ready for some BS when it comes to the Nano Virus. I've started in Japan (makes sense, right?) and within 3 to 5 days, BOLIVIA has grown concerned and started to work on a cure--because of one infected Japanese scientist on the opposite side of the planet.

Still, the game is loads of fun, and I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is available as an App for phones and pads. Get it for that to play something when you need to kill time. Odds are your on Steam on a laptop or desktop and want to play a real game. This just doesn't cut it. On the phone its great. On here, its the phone app just bigger with some clouds and some added information screens. Certainly not enough of an upgrade to warrent $14.99.

I'm sorry but seriously, fifteen dollars? I have games I paid less than 5 dollars for that are more involved with better gameplay and graphics than this. Again I can't say it enough, on your phone or pad, yeah this is a great game. I loved it, still play around on it when I'm killing time. But here, it's just not enough.

Basically you have a world map, pick a country or area and start. As the game goes, clouds move some, boats and planes move around the map, and you occasionally pop bubbles. Sometimes you will have popped enough bubbles to evolve your disease, this part is just another couple of screens with a skill tree, oh and a simple animation of your disease, that will change as you evolve it, you rather will grow as you evolve it, no matter what you chose the picture will change the same way. Illusion of choice. Just not a very good illusion. My other issue with this game is the fact that when you start you can only play as bacteria, you have to beat the game on normal with bacteria to unlock the virus, and so on and so forth. So if you bought this game thinking about making some nanovirus from the future...yeah your not going to be doing that for a while. Cause you will have to unlock it and to do that you will have to play as certain things in certain styles. There are only a couple of for sure ways to beat the game with each type so instead of having the freedom to play as you want, to unlock everything you'll have to play very paticular ways. Again the illusion of choice.

Now on the bright side of things, this is EA and the game will have features and things added in later. Thats great, I suggest maybe then you wait to buy it till its released. However, I'd take real close look at the screenshots, what you see is pretty much what you get.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do I have to explain the awesomeness behind the concept?

I had no idea it was a mobile thing before, apparently it was popular itself, this is essentially that with all the DLC stuff included, far as I can tell; its in Early Access still because they're working on multiplayer functionality (which I personally couldn't care less about in a game like this, destroying the world is MY job goddammit), and platform support, but as far as singleplayer on a windows machine goes it runs flawlessly, and there's plenty of content, though I do think they plan to add more with time (easy to monetize with DLC, you bet your ♥♥♥ they will ^^ and honestly that's fine because it has Steam Workshop support meaning limitless free content). Its harder than you might expect but that's a good thing, the game is rather simple in terms of gameplay (it does feature advanced math to figure out how fast stuff spreads and people die) and it'd get boring if you didn't have to try different combinations to nail a scenario or the sandbox mode.

Also, pay attention to the voice of the guy during the intro video thingie. Some of you (ahem, Half-Life fans) will grin ear to ear ;D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a good game when you want to play solo-strategy.
I played the first Plague on a tablet app,
This second version is just as good with many more choices!

The game is based on the facts of biology and infectious disease.
To win, you need to kill all of earth's population.
There are 3 levels, Casual, Normal and Brutal.

The achievements are very creative. The game is challenging.
I like to play it because it is real science.
A casual game is about 30 mins. Good way to learn,
Normal unlocks achievements. It takes about an hour.
There are at least 5 bio weapons
bacteria, virus, fungus, neurax worm

I'm stuck on fungus at the moment.
It's nice to have a game like this when you feel very curious or very bored.
Because there is no other sim-game like this one.
Yes, it is very creepy but it is darkly humorous too.
It's worth the money and even more, it's worth your time and attention.

Now, do you want to share recipes for swine flu? or bubonic plague?
This is the cookbook for the zombie apocalypse.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Some games you play to build empires. Others you play to shoot things in the head. This one... you play to exterminate humanity. Fun!

Plague Inc: Evolved is a game where you make horrible diseases, spread em around the world, and try to kill everyone before those pesky humans make a cure for your plague. There is strategy involved, but there is some luck too which can be rather frustrating (F***ing Greenland). The game is fun, but also relatively easy to master. Once you figure out how things work, the challenge is mostly gone. Good thing this game has plenty of opportunities for messing around.

The variety comes in the form of each different type of plague having different strengths or weaknesses, like viruses mutating alot which can lead to your disease being detected earlier than you would like. Most of the plagues are real, but the imaginary ones allow for some comic situations to arise. The Neurax Worm allows you to mind control people, leading humans to either kill themselves or worship the worm as a god. And, of course, the Necroa Virus, which allows you to unleash the zombie apocalypse rather than fighting it.

The game can get a bit repetitive in time, but there is alot of crazy fun to be found as well. So, if you want to play a game where murdering everyone is the objective, then this is one that can possibly satisfy. :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Plague Inc: Evolved has evolved beyond its roots as a mobile game, and its inspiration, Pandemic 2. Even at $15, it's worth it.

For those who have only played Pandemic 2 and are wondering if this is better or merely an inferior ripoff, it's definitely a more comprehensive, fleshed-out, less frustrating, more entertaining game, even if the premise is very similar. All the skills (from avian transmission to projectile vomiting) are useful, and while some strategies are more prevalent than others, there's no be-all-end-all way to win the game like there is in Pandemic 2. I'm ten hours in and I'm still finding new ways to win against the odds.

The visuals are vastly improved over the mobile iteration, with red transmission dots forming across the world map as countries fall victim to your plague, 3D renders of your plague hovering in the menus, and image feeds of the cities popping up as they descend from normalcy into chaos.

The devs will be adding online multiplayer, Steam Workshop support, and tutorials (amongst other features) in the upcoming weeks/months, but it's more than playable now and I definitely recommend it if you loved Pandemic and want a superior version of it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not bad for alpha stage. Feels good to be able to destroy humanity :P

The start menu seems promising; there are official scenarios, custom scenarios and even multiplayer. Not accesible at this stage. The options are kind of limited as to how you evolve your pathogen but again it's alpha. You unlock new pathogens everytime you successfully kill everyone and it gets harder to spread the new one. Right now there are 12 pathogens 2 of them not available and i'm stuck at the third one :D

You can mutate your pathogen which is really cool. You can make it resistant to weather conditions, difficult to cure. You can choose how it will spread. Sometimes there are random mutations which might get annoying because you want a sneaky pathogen but the random mutation makes it deadly.

I like the difficulty levels. There are 4. 'Casual, Normal, Brutal, Mega Brutal'. Casual is fairly easy no one washes their hands there are no researches to destroy your pathogen. Normal, some people wash their hands some doctors work so they might discover the sickness. Brutal, THEY LOCK SICK PEOPLE IN PRISON :D Mega brutal, is even worse :D I'm currently playing on brutal and stuck on 3rd pathogen because before i spread it to everyone some countries already restrict access :(

I recommend it but feel like price is a bit high

The main hangup with people seems to be the pricetag.  Seriously people?  Nobody seems to have an issue with paying $40+ on console games.  $15 (to me) is nothing for a game with GREAT replayability and customizability.

If you have played the mobile version then you know what the game is like.  If you haven't, go
download it for free on google play store.

You may be wondering I've played the mobile version
date: why get the PC version?"\nThe PC version has quite a bit more in it
recommended: namely the ability to make your own scenarios!\nNot interested in making any scenarios?  No problem!  There are thousands of custom scenarios available for you to choose from (almost 5
hoursPlayed:
000 as of 4/14/2015).

This is a game that will require a VARYING strategy amidst fairly STATIC gameplay.  Someone posted that it's like the first level of Mario and it only varies in how you get to the end.
Not really true.
They didn't mention that almost everything you do (or don't do!) has a DIRECT impact in-game!

Can you infect the entire world without anyone finding out?  Can you destroy humanity in less than a year?

Bad to bone....Nothing is more awesome than watching your diseased seed spread across the globe!"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI LOVE this game. It's even better than it's old iPad equivalent, Plague Inc. I know some people don't like this game, and that's only because they don't like wiping out the entire world population with a deadly disease. There are plenty of plague types to unlock and each has different gameplay which I find genius. The main game where you pick your disease and kill the world is the main part, but they're already working on (and have released some) other assets to the game such as real-world scenarios like smallpox or the Black Death, as well as random scenarios where nobody cares about poor people. They're even working on a multiplayer race mode to see who can kill everyone the fastest. 10/10. Keep up the good work!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A fun game, still in development (Early Access). You have to control the evolution of the Plague by spending skill points in detailed skill trees. The type of Plagues available to you get unlocked as you progress through the game, you start with only Bacteria available, you will go on to unlock Virus, Fungus, Parasite, Neurax Worm, Prion, Nano-Virus & Bio Weapon. These different Plague types will have either minor or major variations in the evolutions available to you, making for more interesting gameplay! Each game mode is unique in its own way, the different Plagues all seem to have game mechanics independant of each other.

When you beat a level you will unlock different Gene structures, which allow you to get slight boosts or powerups in your future games, these are not needed for the normal difficulty, but can make Brutal or Mega Brutal difficulty go much smoother! There will be more Gene types to come, as this is early access, I have all Gene types unlocked (25/25), but it says that I am only at 83% on Genes unlocked, so we can expect to see more in this department.

Overall the gameplay is fun & challenging. I would definitely say this is in the survival genre with a dash of world domination. If you try it out, you may enjoy it!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have never been into mobile games but based on friends descriptions of this game as soon as it was released on PC I bought it. In it's current state there is still a lot to do and very enjoyable with tons of strategy planning and decision making that makes you pause the game and go through your options. My favorite part of the game is that there is a variety of diseases that all do different things, including a cheat one that gives you access to unlimited resources to evolve your disease as fast or as slow as possible. I would suggest this game to anyone who likes the idea of spreading a disease named whatever you want and seeing if you can infect the entirety of the world and ultimately kill 7 Billion people. It's a game that allows you to play the bad guy which is awesome.

Pros: Music, humor, interface, graphical style, decision making.

Cons: Still in Alpha with a lot of features not yet implemented.

Overall: 9/10 would buy again and will continue to play

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDo you like feeling like a supervillain? Do you like strategy? Newsticker jokes about banning laughter and Canada annexing Alaska? What about terrible things happening to the human body, all for your amusement? If you answered yes to any of the above, this game may be for you. On a more serious note it's a pretty seriously engaging strategy game that balances actually having to think and plan ahead without being so labyrinthine and convoluted to navigate that it stops being fun. The interface is pretty, but might benefit from some streamlining as actually using it takes some practice (though it's perfectly fine once you do get used to it). The sound direction is also very nice.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

i really like this game its fun and addictive, it easily absorbed hours of my day, i find the fungus and neurox worm too be a tad easy but still are my favourites, they both have the best control over the plague and makes you feel as if you have more control over it than the rest of the plagues, i do recomend this game however i do have a few nit picks on the game which i will say soon, but first its shining areas


GOOD AREAS:
1: the map, we all know its hard too put a 3d round object with alot of detail upon a flat surface but the makers in this game in my opinion did well on it, the water and cloud movements added some more immersion it it, so it feels as if oyur looking down upon the earth as your plague spreads. i also like how the plague spreading looked however i will get on that in a sec

2: the news, i really liked the funny easter eggs in them,  plus it makes you have a sense of progress during the game with how the news talked about you

3: plagues, the variety of plagues is really good but i find the differences lacking and the changes in form, how it spreads across the map is really cool it feels as if the country is festering with the plague, and the whole name your own plague bit is awesome

4:traits, i loved how the traits where making the game more interesting upon fast yoiu racked up DNA, transmission symptons and abilities where a hoot too mix and match

5:the models and body scales, i thought it was neat on how you could see how your plague was moving threw the human body inside of the plague menu, and the models of the plagues looked spectacular, however

6:simulation, this game is a great plague simulator and is a good game


BAD AREAS:
1: the models, i know i just praised them but in truth when you add traits too the plague there is only little differences, mostly there are just more and more in the background of the plague, and in the human anatomy area there is very little change but still a nice touch too see how you infect. there is one exception and that is the neurox worm plague you can see it grow on the brain and the tendrils move threw the brain, what i would do is make the other plagues gradually change in appearence threw time. like make the bacteria  grow long or bigger add its own little strings coming of too make it seem more infectous , but again this is just my  opinion im not a critic

2:difficulty, if you have a structered strategy the game feels too easy its only really difficult on the first time playing a plague type, my suggestion add a few minor curve balls like them making a nano cirus too counter act against you and you have too make your plague more lethal too beat the nano virus, just and idea it could be horrible one just saying

3: street view, in it you get the ability too make a street view you only get still frames and what you can see is a bit disapointing there isnt much in them, my suggestion make them change more often too other ones like showing the people infected walking around or the healthy wearing doctors masks. just a suggestion this isnt a game breaking thing...unlike the next one

4: the curser, i dont know if anyone else has had this problem but my curser sometimes doesnt work or doesnt click the rihgt one, how? for examply i had too click four times on a ability ounce just too highlight it, it gets annoying especially when you buy one and arent paying attention and go too buy another and you accidently de-evolve the trait you just got, i was playing nano virus and had nearly killed humanity and went too buy organ failure aaaand i sold coma and got 2 DNA points back and didnt have enough too buy coma back and organ failure


5:news, even with how the news makes you feel acomplished, it still repeats it self and has little variety thats just minor though

6: the cure, dont get me wrong i love how it works but if you up transmission and the medical resistance tree it just doesnt even matter, half of the time when i upped the med tree so much i forgot about the cure and destroid humanity with it 40% done



even with all that ive said this game is a wonderful game and i recomend it too any who want too just kill time, its fun some times funny and with the game in early access the game has alot of bugs but there minor and you can just have fun with it. so i recomend this game

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWho hasn't always wanted to create a plague to destroy humanity? Well, alright to be fair most people haven't. But it is strangely satisfying to do in this game. The depth in each plague is just outstanding and a fun puzzle to solve. What worked in one plague may be your downfall in another. That kind of experience keeps me coming back for more and more, trying to overcome every obstacle laid out. While 14.99 does seem a tad steep for the content you get, the inevitable content makes it worth it and then some. Having put a lot of hours into the Android version and now working my way up on the PC version, it's a must have for anyone who enjoys a good strategy game. It's casual, it's fun, you won't regret it as a purchase. As a bonus, constant patching and content keep this a refreshing game. Just buy it and thank me later.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After playing the iOS version of Plague Inc. I was slightly skeptical if a PC version could actually be any different and more enjoyable. Currently, it's holding up better than its iOS version and the regular updated with fresh content keeps me regularly coming back to try them out. Apart from that though the replayabiltiy seems to lose its appeal after you've completed each plague a couple of times ( unless you really care about completing each disease on the hardest difficulty ).

Sadly the scenario mode doesn't really offer much difference from playing as a regular plague, albeit with a few preset evolutions and different human interaction. The real stand out features are the Neurax Worm and Necroa Virus, both of which work very differently to the regular plagues. Whereas each disease follows a similar concept, evolve symptoms and transmission until you've infected most the world, then start killing people. The Neurax Worm & Necroa Virus offer different methods of completion, taking control of humanity through the Worm, or driving the human race to extinction through zombies with the Necroa.

The Simian flu is essentially an altered version of the Necroa virus created as a tie in for the Planet of the Apes move, I don't have a problem with it, and its definitely a nice addition, but it all feels a bit too familiar after you've turned everyone in to a flesh eating zombie a few times over.

Overall the game is definitely worth purchasing, even while its in early access, although you might find yourself a bit bored as you approach the 30 hour mark, the frequent updates will keep you regularly coming back to try out new features and try your hand at the scenarios again.

8/10
+Regularly updated, simplistic design, cool plagues, Zombies
- Gets boring after 24 hours or so, scenarios are a bit basic.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Plague Inc is a break from the average genres and themes you typically see in video games.

You see, the objective of this game is to destroy the world with a...wait for it...plague. (Unexpected, right?) However, you have no direct control over the plague. Instead, you give it different abilities that sort of guide it throughout the world. That's the best part. You start at point A (One person infected), and you need to get to point B (Everyone dead). How you get there is up to you and your play style, and strategies vary from round to round depending on your traits and the enviroment around you. It basically boils down to a race against the clock, and it can actually be pretty engaging. One other good thing to be said is that it is a great time-waster. If you need to kill an hour or two or just want to play something casual, this game is great.

In short, Plague Inc is a interesting strategy title that brings in elements from simulation games. It sometimes feels more like a mobile app than a PC game, but nonetheless it is unique enough to consider buying.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nEver secretly wished you worked for Umbrella Corporation, spreading despair and disease one bioweapon at a time? Well now you get to live out that sick fantasy, like a true Albert Wesker-in-training! Plague Inc. is rather morbid in its conception, but the gameplay is so fun you often forget that you're in control of ending the world itself. The disease types and modifications are varied and interesting, from a simple parasite to a virus responsible for turning people into zombies-- making for differing challenges each time. It requires a good deal of patience and strategy to make it through. I love the attention to detail in this game, it adds to the realism. The graphics are simple but effective:  Slowing watching a map of the entire earth as it goes from green (healthy), to red (infected), all the way to a grim black (death) is strangely satisfying.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWho hasn't always wanted to create a plague to destroy humanity? Well, alright to be fair most people haven't. But it is strangely satisfying to do in this game. The depth in each plague is just outstanding and a fun puzzle to solve. What worked in one plague may be your downfall in another. That kind of experience keeps me coming back for more and more, trying to overcome every obstacle laid out. While 14.99 does seem a tad steep for the content you get, the inevitable content makes it worth it and then some. Having put a lot of hours into the Android version and now working my way up on the PC version, it's a must have for anyone who enjoys a good strategy game. It's casual, it's fun, you won't regret it as a purchase. As a bonus, constant patching and content keep this a refreshing game. Just buy it and thank me later.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, having played 16 hours of this game so far I should write a review about my experience with it.

I'll just start off by saying it's fun. I wouldn't have played 16 hours of it if it wasn't.

The basis of Plague Inc, make a plague and try to exterminate humanity (though some plagues allow different endings, with the Neurax worm you can either make them slaves to the parasite or have the parasite tell them to all commit suicide, and with the Necroa virus you can kill off all of humanity with a horde of zombies infected by the virus, there are also different endings with other plagues in the official scenarios, one of which reverts humanity back to neanderthals).

Evolving your plague and watching it's influence on the ingame world is interesting, you can slowly make the pathogen more severe and kill off the world in a very drawn out fashion or you can hide your plague, wait until everybody is infected and evolve it to be extremely lethal and watch society go from modern day to human extinction in a week. The news ticker on the top of the in game interface will reflect the state of the world and you will notice the ticker change as your plague changes, it's one thing that I like about the game, though eventually you will get to the point where you've seen it all as events usually happen multiple times throughout multiple playthroughs.

I have a few gripes about the game, one of which is that you can use one tactic to pass a good amount of the plagues almost 100% of the time regardless of how difficult it is, but for the ones you can't use this tactic on I will note that Mega-Brutal difficulty is really.. really.. Brutal. As it should be, I've yet to pass some plagues after trying them repeatedly with different tactics on the difficulty, and I like that. Eventually I'll find the right combination at the right time, though thats not to say there is only one combination set for every plague, you can try many things, but generally there will be a few tactics that are both fast and efficient that should be used.

To those who have played the game on the phone, you won't be seeing much new here other than a prettier interface and 3d graphics. Though there will be more content later down the line, right now the phone and PC version of the game are pretty much identical.

In the end, is the game worth 15 dollars? Yes, though the game doesn't have a significant amount of replayability after you beat a plague on mega brutal with 5 stars, getting to that point took me over 10 hours, and even then I'm not completely done with all plagues, so the journey up to that point is a long but enjoyable one. There is promise for custom scenario support and mutliplayer in the future, which will hopefully make the game even better.

tl;dr: The game is fun, and can be extremely difficult at tougher difficulties, the future updates promised look good and I don't regret paying for the game while in early access.

reviewText:
Since it is on the front page of Steam today with its full release, I shall post my review.
Plague, Inc: Evolved is about creating a pathogen however you want, and then attempting to destroy the world.
The singleplayer is already good enough for people who like strategy.
There are scenarios with custom pathogens and interesting countermeasures.
Then, recently, they added VS multiplayer. This mode is excellent, becoming an even more strategic battle between strategists.
With the full release out of early access, they have added co-op multiplayer which I haven't tried yet but I'd imagine it's excellent. I urge you to buy this game, if it appeals to you in the slightest. It's even 10% off at launch!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I made a bacteria where I made it evolve to make people diarrhea AND vomit at the same time until they die. I just guided the symptoms and stuff. Then I got the notice in game that people were pooping in the streets and throwing up at the same time.

There are many other just straight disease types [virus, bacteria, fungus, zombie virus/etc] but also has scenarios where the world is set up a certain way and you are a specific disease made with it's own stuff or just a general one like above. Or you can make your own diseases using the several types as a base.

This game is great with each disease having it's own balance to win. With fungus, you need to really focus on spreading right. It doesn't spread like a virus, you have to plan when to do a spore release. Eventually you can evolve it so powerful that the whole world just has spores in the air. But you need to get the evolution points first.. which takes planning. So you can get crazy power but you have to think it through.

Many great difficulties each describing exactly how it effects the game.

Researchers and other stuff, among other 'enemies' in the game depend on your selection. But always end up starting to make a cure. Oh I'm sorry researchers is it hard to see through the microscope while bleeding out of your eyes? Does the cure become easier to find when you got sick too and now your organs are shutting down? Watch the lab! Don't want to poop all over those samples.

Oh wait, no, it's because your whole country is dying and has a few thousand survivors just waiting to die. Good luck getting the lab grant to fund research!

Oh and there is a Neurax Worm alien type disease. It is a creature that attaches to the brain stem, and spreads with eggs but you can modify it's evolution do spread and grow other ways. My favorite is to make the infected obsessed with putting eggs in people's food and hijacking planes to fly into countries that tried to shut out the world.

Then you can evolve so the Neurax causes them to all enjoy suicide. And another where they worship the worm and start  becoming a religion. If everyone gets infected you win and all humankind now worship the alien things.

My favorite though, aside from making zombies that evolve in crazy ways and the millions of ways to enjoy the game...

Is when you get a notice that what ever you started as, you had now caused the human race to go extinct.

Because it can happen, several diseases rocked human civilization, and the game doesn't let you forget.

20/20 would poop and vomit at the same time again. Gotta go now, there is a neighborhood gathering. Some worms that you put on your neck and it's supposed to feel really good. Free caviar too!

---

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do you like simulations? Do you like strategy? Do you like killing stuff? Do you like answering my questions? This is probably the game for you if you answered yes to at least the first three of the four previous questions.
This game features many virus and plagues and much more down the line such as a zombiotic disease and even a simiam disease where you can control zombies or apes and kill off the entire world. This game lets you literally re-enact the Black Plague that the world suffered from ages ago.
Other features include evolving your disease, choosing its abilities and symptoms, and so on. You can even watch the world news feed as comical headlines scroll past, such as Swedish miner trapped in mine
date: freed by Microsoft. Rides into sunset". Any Minecraft player would probably understand the reference the game made there.\nAll in all

reviewText:
Early Access Review

---------------------------------------------------------------
I ALWAYS WANTED TO BE AN INTERNATIONAL TERRORIST.
---------------------------------------------------------------

OK seriously, how can something so bad be so much fun? This game is so wrong but at the same time so ♥♥♥♥ing great. TL;DR below.

So you have a disease which can be in the form of many things (virus, bacteria, worm, and like 10 more). You choose one form and start a game.

You infect one person in a country of your choice. Then you start modifying the disease. So it can spread and kill. Add abilities to increase transmission rates between humans or add strength to the virus so it's harder to eradicate.

You can modify it further to slow down the cure research progress. Oh yes, rich countries are working on a cure. You didn't just expect them to sit on their asses and watch did you? Canada, Japan, Germany, ♥♥♥♥ing health fascists send planes around the world to spread cure research.

As your disease spreads and kills more people, ♥♥♥♥ happens. Borders, sea ports and airports start closing down. Previously issued drug safeguards are removed in the name of a faster research.

Martial laws are put in effect. Governments fall, people rage around killing, looting, dying.

And all you do is, WATCH.

TL;DR:
- The game has a high replayability value since there are different game modes and scenarios.
- There is stuff to unlock
- For some reason I like the soundtrack
- I like the sound effects
- Simple design
- Accurate country populations
- Funny news bulletins if you read them
- Advance into harder and more interesting game modes
- Kill the whole world with disease mutating

This game is a unique must-have. It should be in everybody's library. It's really fun. It turned even ME, a born humanist, into a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ terrorist.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is pretty fun. It does a lot of things that the flash game equivalents do, but adds some neat features that keep things fresh. I think as long as it keeps getting updates and fulfills its promises of multiplayer and custom scenarios, etc. etc., it could be more than worth the pricetag. As of now it's still good and still fairly worth it, especially for those that like macro-scale world domination games or the disease theme like this. Even if you're not a hundred percent on board with games like this, I'd say it's still worth a try.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Virus strategy games are making leaps and bounds. I was really looking forward to such games to come to the Steam Market.
For years now I've been playing a little flash game called Pandemic"
date: of which this is like the parent of. This game is absolutely great. It's difficult to beat
recommended: really makes you think and it does hold your hand a little
hoursPlayed:
but scoots you on your merry way.

Pandemic was a simple interface. You clicked maybe three or four buttons. Start in random counties. Told you when all borders were closed or all flights are gone. Check boxes for symptoms and infectivity. Still let me enjoy killing time.

Pandemic 2 was more difficult. You had to watch a video tutorial to understand more about this game. For a flash game
voteText: bringing in a more RTS feel to it was alright. At the time it puzzled me and made me turn my nose
helpfulPercent: heading back for the first game.\n\nHowever
votesHelpful: this is about Plague Inc.\n\nOnly a few hours in and the fun and frustration is flooding back to me. You can say a hearty "F*&# you

commentsCount: first!" But when you're initially going to infect them
column16: you notice little icons above their information. The fact that they've incoorperated statuses like Wealth
column17: Humidity
column18:
Hot or Cold gives a major challange. Finding places that are less rural and more densely populated is great for growing viruses. You have to take more into account when you're trying to spread your nasty plague upon the world.

My advice? Do buy this game. Help the developers become a pandemic (Hehe) upon this market.
It is definitely worth the $15.00 and the tasty demo on Android really got me into this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a bit difficult to explain how great this game is. Yes, you're killing all of humanity in an incredibly morbid way. But at the same time, there's a sense of accomplishment, which I guess would come from killing everyone, after all. But when you finally figure out how to kill humanity correctly, it feels amazing. Did I mention the fact that you kill humanity? Its pretty cool. Anyways, like I was saying, it feels great to unlock that new desease types, and the new infection thing. The game is incredibly expansive and has tons of replayibility.

Now for a few cons! The game is a bit buggy for me, which of course comes with the territory with these early access games, but it never really gets in the way too much when playing the game. Another con that's not really a big deal is the fact that the max resoulution is extreamly low, but in all honesty it looks amazing regardless.

One of the best purchases Iv'e made on steam for awhile, I rate this game 8/10 at its early access state.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAwesome strategy game, and thats coming from someone who never plays them, ever. I recieved the game as a gift and I think its really fun. Its kind of like a stress reliever, wiping out the human race with a wide range of official and community created plagues, virsus, and bacterias. Its not one of those sit down for a quick session games though, depending on how in depth you want to get evolving your plague, a game can run upwards of about 45 minutes, unless your just really good at games like this. I still recommend it though!

Greetings fellow gamers! This is Gamer Guy (In a Suit) from the Echo Army YouTube channel! Today I am bringing you a review of an intriguing little Simulator-type game called Plague, Inc. Plague, Inc has been around on mobile devices for a while, and on Steam since February 20, 2014. It is still in Early Access, but Publisher/Developer Ndemic Creations is VERY active, having just recently added the highly anticipated Competitive Multiplayer mode.


(NOTE: This was a review from a game in my own Steam library, it was NOT provided by the Developer and/or Publisher)


Video Review:

https://youtu.be/60mmrRezNlE

The Too Long
recommended:
good casual way to pass time OR you can ramp up the difficulty and give yourself fits. Highly replayable. Active Devs. Another 4/5 on an incomplete game? Yup. Worth $15 easily.

The "Meat & Potatoes" Review:

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Honestly loved the game, finished enough to enjoy 10-20 hours of gameplay which is surprising for early access.

I understand its a reboot of a phone ap that cost .99 cents but they charge 2-4 dollars per plague type which is half the gameplay. So in the end 15 is worth it. I felt like the game was worth the full ammount in its current condition. With that been said I'm super excited  for the full release. Couldn't find a bug(a possible spelling error is all). Just one or 2 balancing issues.
Like I said though this game is better than most finished games out there!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Have you ever wanted to destroy human-kind with a deadly virus? well, now you can!

That cheesy start line aside, Plague Inc: Evolved is by far an addicting game. If you enjoyed the flash game Pandemic then I have no doubt in my mind that you will love this addicting little number. Now, If you're not familiar with the game, you basically choose a disease and plot to infect humanity with various transmissions and abilities.

It takes something so tragic and to be quite frank, utterly horrible disasters and makes it enjoyable to figure out your plagues strength and weaknesses and in effect destroy the world as quickly as possible without being cured. All that being said, it does teach how dangerous and quickly one tiny little bug can spread if gone undetected or if you go for the quick kill route, even dead bodies can be infectious which is where the danger really amplifies.

I hate to drop the educational word as it tends to make games lose their appeal to some, but it really is without you even noticing. Having to tailor make each decision of evolving certain things to make it more lethal, infectious, to be harder to cure or to be hardier in cold environments etc. It gives you a sense of how they work as well as perhaps opening a different pathway for said virus. Given it may not be 100% accurate, it's still a good perception of it.

Within the main game you begin playing as the starter bug; bacteria. The most common thing and the easier one to beat to then unlock more complex virus's, and then in the next selection, extra add on's such as a start game bonus of DNA points and such. You can make it to suit your own play-style once you learn how the game works, which makes it so much more appealing.

Now, from a completely different viewpoint, it can be seen that you're commanding these viruses to in simple, destroy everything. Which in itself is a fun stress reliever.

With the recent update of it being added to Steam Workshop, you are able to make some amazing scenarios as well as download some incredibly done ones from other people, just that expands the game so, so much.

Not to repeat myself, but it does again add onto my constant point of how Steam Greenlight brings out a lot of talent that may generally get overlooked. With most of these games, the active development is incredible, so much work goes into keeping these games updated and bug free, especially this one. Also getting involved in making Christmas events are a nice sign of things to come for catered game modes and what not for different life events, I for one, love that. It gives the game character in the sense that it's basically involved in current events.

To conclude, this is an amazing game that I would recommend wholeheartedly, it's one that keeps on giving and deserves all the support possible.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI usually don't review games, actually usually is an overstatement.. I dont think I ever have reviewed a game but this as an upcoming title and early access I feel that it deserves some recognition. This is a great rendition of Plague Inc, this reboot has brought me hours of nostalgic trial and error fun. The days playing the old flash game in school never got old I guess. The game brings from what I have experienced and stated above, hours of trial and error fun. The game is polished and looks great. A certain thing I feel I could bring up though are that in the fungus level, at least on the lower difficulties and I also believe on Brutal you can exploit the refund system to gain points by constantly refunding spore burst abilities. I love the depth and scenarios this game offers and I am looking forwards to see how it pans out. A well-spent 15 dollars and a small but great addition to my steam library.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me start off by saying i played this game since the Mobile version.

I never expected for a Mobile game to become such a great computer game. I was pretty addicted on getting everything completed on the mobile, and after i finished most of the things it was a big boner killer. Then now, the computer Version arrived which was a breath of fresh air :)

The Game is very pretty graphically, i also love the themes in question of trying to help to Donate to certain non-profits in-game making the gamers aware of what goes on. The game is basically just like the Mobile version but in a Prettier and more detailed Version . You get to understand the countries, weakenessess and strenghts of viruses better, the spread of the virus looks way cooler, and there's also everything unlocked (not having to buy in pieces like the mobile version)

Overall, i enjoy the game a lot and for now i give a 8.5/10 for the game.

What i would like to See enhanced/Improved?

More Music tracks, more viruses/Evolution. Maybe a Virus versus Cure mode Online?(thats just a wild dream), Some perks on the way you can play mechanically.

Its a Early Access game so i do have high hopes for the future :) Keep the great Work!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI remember playing this game in it's free browser incarnations and it was a simple, challenging, and enjoyable game. This PC version is SO MUCH MORE! When the game first came out I didn't get it because it sold game features a la carte -- and I vote with my dollars when it comes to things like that, taking a pass until it was being sold all in one peice. I'm glad I came back to get it! The interface is both familiar and developed, and you can have great fun evolving your disease, over and over again, to see how it does best. Runaway killer? Insideous hidden plague? Airborne? Waterborne? you can pick numerous different paths for each disease in how it is transmitted, it's symptoms, and it's abilities. What's best is the variety of different plagues. From simple bacteria, to mutating viruses, to zombie plagues, mind control parasites, and on and on -- great replayablility. The main game is fun enough -- then you realize there are a bunch of scenarios that add even more to the game! A great and unique sim. Worth a look.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After playing this on an Android tablet through a couple of plagues, I became addicted to this game.
I went to the website and found it was also on iPhone and PC, and ended up buying the versions for each. This game, while not action-packed, is definitely for those who love strategy. This game has plenty.

Don't be fooled by Casual and Normal difficulties, where it first appears that the strategies are all the same. The real challenge lies in Brutal and Mega Brutal difficulties, where everything you do has a serious consequence. At those difficulty levels, each plague becomes unique, and managing them to beat the cure is no easy task. You really have to plan and think your way through each, and even then random events can derail you. I haven't even gotten to the scenarios yet - can't wait to try them, once I finish all the plagues and unlocking all the genes.

I highly recommend this to the strategy fans everywhere.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am obviously not very good at this game because I have only unlocked 2 levels so far, viruses and fungi. (along with bacteria, which is what you start with to infect the world and wipe out the human race), but this game is a lot deeper than it first appears.  In a way, it's kind of like Risk, in the sense that you essentially need to infect (capture) each state on the map, and then wipe out the humans before they have time and resources to fight back, but the challenge is that unless you do things just right, a well laid plan can backfire pretty easily.

Having said that, I've already dumped a good 20 hours into the game so far, and it keeps me coming back for more.  You get to know when you've blown it and have to do the game over after a few raounds of play, but eventually you figure out what strategy you need to do to win with the particular plague you are given.  At least partly.  There are enough randome elements thrown in such as unexpected mutations, unexpected actions such as the pesky humans putting filters in aircraft which can hinder your ability to spread.  Getting to the islands of Greenland and New Zealand (among several others) can make or break a game.  If there are ANY humans left alive at the end, you lose, full stop.

But I would say this game is very well thought out (and appearenly a hit in it's previous mobile form) and even though it's not finished it's one of those games that just keeps yanking you back for more.  Just ONE more try, just one more round, and to me, that's when you are getting your money's worth in a strategy game.

If you like risk, chess, or any world domination type game, this is definitely one to check out.  One warning, it's not finished yet, so there are still features like custom scenarios coming.  But don't worry, you have to get through multiple plagues to unlock all of them, and then you have to actually beat the game about 10 more times to unlock all of the buffs that you can get for your plagues at the start of each game.

I don't know about anyone else, but I look foward to playing a few rounds each night.  Yes, I have lost sleep over this, and that's a sign of a great game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I started out playing this game through various free flash gaming sites back in high school and continued playing it on mobile devices well into 2013. This is THE definitive version of Plague Inc. Essentially it simulates the capabilities that a pathogen could have to spread and wipe out the human race. A wide array of infection options await ranging anywhere from the common virus to prions, bioweapons, fungi, and even some more interesting fictional ones like the undead plague, brain-invading worms, and with the most recent update the Simian Flu from the Planet of the Apes movies.

Add to the fact of how addictive this game can be and its totally worth the price.

Early Access Review

Have you played pandemic 1 or even 2? (and possibly Plague inc)

well, you could say that this game 'evolves' upon the others; it features alot more custimisation, diseases and looks much prettier with the 3d models and 'hud'.

The way plagues spread is very realistic, and it can both terrify you and excite you as you watch how humanity chokes on their last breath with each enhancement of your plague.

*shivers* ahhh, it's that brilliant; but it gets better especially when you get your hands on the 'neurax worm'. oh how amazing it is :'D  Just the way it  'hugs' your brain and manipulates your every move, you can even make humanity think your their God!

Zombies: yep, the things that eat your brain, well... used too. Now they just blood thirsty decaying bodies that CLAW AT YOUR FACE!

Oh, and hopefully you know that it's a strategy game.

Thank you for  reading this 'review' and hopefully you buy the game, it'll really help the developers to make this great game even better!


On a side note: it features a planet of the apes disease :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Play God for once in this brilliant strategy game about contagion and extinction.

Plague Inc. Evolved sets you, a human being behind the keyboard, in the world of viral outbreaks, bacteriological contagion, and man-made epidemics set from whatever date you start playing all the way to years from now, in which your virus can either destroy or be destroyed.

The game offers various scenarios with your choice of different types of plague to choose from. Each plague has a genomic upgrade, unlocked throughout your playtime, which could make your plague superior. After that, it's all about location, location, location. Any country can start this epidemic and every country can be infected, but no country is safe.

Currently, as of Aug. 4, 2014(the date of this review), it's under construction to include a few new ways of transmitting diseases, to symptoms that could resemble everyone's favorite apocalypse, to abilities that could hinder the efforts of curing diseases, but that's not all. You will be able to create NEW SCENARIOS in the custom scenarios slot. You can mutate the common cold or make Bedbugs become the prime transmitter of your disease or redo the black plague(even though that's already a scenario in the game) which kills in a month.

Overall, the game is not complete, and with current games all for flash, bang, boom, instead of thought provoking gameplay, you won't keep entertained if you're simply a COD fan. However, if you want to play God, doom the earth to suffer the worst plague of mankind, and feel like a villain, then what are you waiting for??? YOU MOTHER, GET UP! COME ON! GET DOWN WITH THE SICKNESS!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As many have said, this game is extremely similar to the original mobile version but nicer looking, there are a few differences here and there but even the messages that pop up are basically the same. That being said, once you reach the neurax worm (Necroa isn't yet available) I found myself VERY much enjoying it, this new one is very interesting and very new.

Unfortunatly, once you have played the neurax one, it's a little harder to go back to the others as they tend to resemble each other a lot, like in the handheld. I think if there were more different types or a deeper gene system it could make the game very interesting.

Overall, I would say the game has a lot of potential, by adding new messages and events to shake things up, a few new plagues that differ like the neurax worm, this could be amazing! There are still a lot of features that aren't implemented since this IS early access, but I'd say if you're interested, 15 dollars isn't quite so bad. I recommend it, but cautiously.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Coming from someone who didn't buy the Pandemic version of the game and someone who is into different strategy games, I really enioy this. I feel that you can get enough hours out of the game that the price as it stands now is justified. The way the game is now, without the promised multiplayer, already can give you tens of hours of playing time which is really all I can ask for out of a game like this.

Although only a few hours in, I find countless reasons why I should get back on the game instead of doing other things. Only having access to one type of disease from the start encourages you to keep playing in order to unlock the others, among other things like obtaining achievements or even just conquering different difficulty levels and testing different strategies gives the game an incredible amount of replay value.

I absolutely dig the simple but sweet design of the game as well. Something about playing on a simple map in HD with good particle effects just is really fun. The menus are very easy to navigate and understand and overall it looks really polished.

Some people claim that this game can be boring in the sense that they claim all you are doing is clicking and waiting, but I disagree. Although this game doesn't require as much attention as some other games that I have played, you clearly make strategic decisions throughout your game in order to go about spreading your disease but at the same time trying to keep a low profile so you are not noticed before spreading the entire globe. You are continuously involved by clicking bubbles that appear on the screen for DNA points" that you use to go about "leveling up" your disease through different transmission methods
hoursPlayed: I enjoy reading and reacting to some of the random "news" events which may contribute to my playstyle. For example if bird migration was up
voteText: I may consider using my DNA points to make transmission with birds more effective among many other things.\n\nI suppose I can go on all day with this but i'll just finish with saying that I am excited to check out the multiplayer in the future and finally just see how this game turns out when it is officially released."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While some people might consider this game to be too expensive, I strongly disagree. Plague Inc. started as a relatively simple phone app. Now it is evolving into a full-flegded pc-game. It has appealing visuals, a ridiculous amount of replay value and can be quite challenging if you wish it to be. Not to mention the (very) regular updates. And let us not forget that it's an early access game, it'll only get bigger and better.

I'd give this game a 9/10 rating, would recommend to my friends.
